text: Another week has flown by. I drove past the new house yesterday and noticed that the front window was covered in boxes. We may receive the keys at closing, and I am getting increasingly excited. Provided everything goes smoothly this week, we will be set for closing a week from Wednesday. I stayed up until after 3:00am last night watching movies with Bethany. There has been a lot of movie-watching activity around here recently. Here's my summary: last night we watched "Thirteen," a film that every mother of a teenager should see. It exceeded my expectations. Next, we watched "Gigli," which lived down to its negative reputation, but we felt compelled to witness its notoriety firsthand.

Summer TV used to be a dead zone filled with reruns, but now there are two great new shows that I've been watching religiously for the past week. One show features hairstylist Jonathan Antin, who wants to open a second location for his wildly popular West Hollywood salon - this time in Beverly Hills. While it wouldn't normally pique my interest, I happened to catch a glimpse of Jonathan speaking passionately about his plans to create "the greatest salon in the history of the world" while standing in an empty space on Rodeo Drive. His confident yet narcissistic demeanor made him strangely captivating, reminding me of Rocco from a previous reality show.

"What a week! I've developed tendinitis in my right shoulder, located just beneath my shoulder blade. Whenever I move my arm excessively, particularly while using a computer mouse, it's excruciating. I've been unable to move it much lately due to a prolonged period of updating my website and working on various online projects. Consequently, I've struggled to muster the energy to draw anything. Lack of sleep has only exacerbated the pain. Needless to say, I'm not exactly thrilled at the moment, but I'm optimistic about recovery. Thankfully, my mother's surgery went smoothly, and her eyesight has slightly improved. Although she remains largely blind, she can now distinguish fuzzy shapes and recognize colors. We hope that her vision will fully recover soon."

"Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how quickly the simplest tasks can become a daunting ordeal. I also discovered how incredibly kind complete strangers can be, simply because they choose to be. Believe me, it wasn't as if they were trying to win me over or gain favor; I had children dripping slobber all over me and was dressed in my 'laundry day' attire. Moreover, I'm not entirely convinced I'll ever bathe again, so there wasn't even a remote olfactory motivation at play! At present, I am concurrently crafting a post and enjoying No Doubt music videos. I'm doing both from the comfort of my desktop computer in my bedroom."

It's 11:14 PM MST, and I'm sitting in my bedroom, repairing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. While I don't mind lending a hand, I can't help but wonder how frequently I end up fixing others' computers as a favor. I'm grateful for the opportunity to assist and serve people in this way, but I do ponder where the boundary lies when it comes to being taken advantage of. Over the past few weeks, I've been staying up late reading and such, so I was eager to hit the hay early. However, I soon realized it would be wiser to return the computer to its owner before getting some shut-eye. As they say, "no rest for the weary," right? Consequently, I found myself watching Joe Schmo 2 again tonight.

Remind me, what was I writing about before this? Or shall I say, another installment in the 'is this a date?' saga. So, after that peculiar lunch, my self-assurance wavered, and I neglected to share a crucial detail with you all. Prior to Pat's arrival at the luncheon, Dustin started expounding on what a great guy Pat is and his efforts to find him a romantic partner. As I listened and nodded, I couldn't help but notice that our conversation had shifted from discussing topics with a stranger over pink lemonade to finding Dustin's ideal match. Feeling uneasy, I excused myself to the restroom, gazed into the mirror, and quietly questioned my own thoughts: Was I being set up with someone else? Is this the new norm?

I urge everyone to reflect before acting. In fact, I wish each person would dedicate themselves to constant contemplation, starting from the moment they wake up and continuing throughout their day. If they're unwilling or unable to do so, then perhaps it's best they return to sleep and indulge in an endless slumber. I've had my fill of mindless individuals. Now, I don't claim to possess exceptional intelligence, but I believe it's reasonable to expect people to demonstrate basic cognitive abilities. Let's concentrate on a select few instances today and reserve others for later. Sounds agreeable, yes? Excellent!

Two issues with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. While Bush has stimulated the economy, he has done so in the wrong manner. As Robert Rubin pointed out to NPR's Marketplace, Bush could have achieved the same level of stimulus without incurring long-term debt by implementing targeted, temporary tax cuts that benefited low- and middle-income individuals. Ah, Robert Rubin - his name alone brings a sense of credibility to economic discussions. Need proof? Try naming another Bush administration cabinet member with Rubin's stature on domestic policy. Take your time; it might take a moment... 2. Unfortunately, we cannot entrust Republicans with power exclusively during times of war, as they have cleverly manufactured a never-ending, worldwide "War on Terror" pretext.

She's claiming I'm on the run, pursuing men for entertainment. Haven't posted an update in a while, but nothing significant to report... Visited the cove to watch Supernothing, and they performed well, as usual. Had the opportunity to relax with Tiago :-) Saturday arrived, and I went to work followed by an evening out with Joe, Rachel, Steve, Tiago, and Tom. Returned home at nearly midnight and rose early the next day at quarter past six for a meeting. Arrived a tad late, but all was well; I delivered a solid performance, executing a complete routine on the floor exercise and avoided falling. Secured second place on both the floor and vault, third on balance beam, and achieved an overall score of 29.45, which wasn't terrible since my performances tend to improve throughout the season.

Do you ever have moments when you start to ponder life? Like when you're sitting in math class, bored senseless, and you wonder what processes in your brain allow you to comprehend math? And then it dawns on you - you're not just passively receiving information, but actively existing and participating in this moment. It's a remarkable realization, isn't it? But then, you might also notice how strange it is to be having these thoughts in the first place. I mean, who has time for existential musings during math class? It's almost as if our minds are wired to seek meaning and connection wherever we can find them, even in the most mundane situations. As for block schedules, I agree that they can be challenging. It's hard to stay engaged and focused for such long periods of time, especially when the subject matter gets increasingly complex. Perhaps there's a way to balance the need for in-depth learning with more frequent breaks and opportunities for movement and refreshment. What do you think?

I believe that Monopoly has run its course in my life, and I vow to never touch that accursed iron again (not a hot one, but the game piece). Tonight, Andy defeated me by a narrow margin and won the fateful game, or perhaps I allowed him to triumph due to his impending departure and my desire for him to depart feeling content. Regardless of the circumstances, my Texas-sized headache currently takes precedence; I've ingested some Aleve, which seems to be effective. All I require now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation. Your phone was the instrument that facilitated my wrapping the cord around your neck...at the drive-in.

Well, today has been a long day. We had to drive home from Indiana. I suppose I'll need to be selective about what I write about since I could easily ramble on and use up too much time and space. However, I must say that camp was incredible and exceeded my expectations. God has been working wonders in my life lately, and it's truly amazing. I've made some positive changes in my life, but let me start from the beginning. We arrived at the Twiggs' house on Friday evening and spent the weekend there before leaving for camp on Monday. Our activities mainly consisted of attending the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watching movies.

Today is my last day of summer vacation! Oh no! And I have a dentist appointment at 9 am. I'm not thrilled about it, but I'd prefer to get it out of the way rather than trying to schedule it during the chaotic first month of my surgery rotation. I'm feeling pretty anxious about starting this new chapter in my life - nervous, apprehensive, uneasy, and a bit terrified, to be exact. As a perfectionist, I thrive on mastering whatever I set my mind to, but beginning something new can be daunting. I dislike being in an unfamiliar situation where I feel like I'm just along for the ride, and I detest not having all the information I need.

Arun Shourie highlights how TV Rajeswar, the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh, had cautioned as early as 1996 about the looming danger of a potential "third Islamic state" in the subcontinent. In a sequence of articles published in Hindustan Times, Rajeswar, who was then the Head of Intelligence Bureau and currently serves as the Governor of Uttar Pradesh, forecasted this menacing prospect. Shourie poses a legitimate question when he wonders whether the fact that Rajeswar, rather than he (Shourie) or Mr. Advani, penned those pieces makes the alerts more credible. Or, does it lead one to assume that Rajeswar harbors covert communal leanings and therefore ought not to hold the office of Governor of Uttar Pradesh?

Attitude: Boredom permeates my mood, feeling rather indifferent yet eagerly anticipating tonight's respite after enduring a grueling day in the trenches. Unfortunately, I haven't had much time to dedicate to writing for you, dear readers. Nevertheless, it's heartening to witness Tigger (now AKCron) assume control and share her thoughts, discussing various matters with enthusiasm. While there isn't much to report, I must mention that attending Shakespeare on the Green was a delightful experience, despite having to depart before the final curtain call, which left me feeling somewhat unsatisfied. Hopefully, one day I'll have the opportunity to watch an entire Shakespearean play from start to finish. Getting back on track, AKCron raises valid points regarding the shower situation; its shortcomings are undeniable. Admittedly, the facial expressions people make while engaging in self-flagellation in the shower can be quite amusing.

All of a sudden, I've been experiencing intense episodes of fatigue over the past two days. Bone-deep exhaustion has left me feeling debilitated. Last night, I returned home and fell into such a deep sleep that I didn't stir until my mother called me around 8:30 PM. When I finally opened my eyes, the room was pitch black, and I couldn't tell what time or day it was for a few disorienting moments. My mother's voice echoed through the darkness as I struggled to regain my bearings. Despite the nice weather today, I'm still feeling unusually drained. Interestingly, Calcutta has been experiencing continuous rain for the past three days.

Last night was dreadful. I discarded the sweater I was crafting. I had barely 14 inches completed. I estimate I squandered around $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 per skein). However, the garment featured an excessive number of stitches by the time I reached the armholes, and the mohair kept tangling together as I knitted, making it difficult to frog (rip out rows) effectively. The yarn broke frequently. Surprisingly, I refrained from cursing, which is uncharacteristic of me. Instead, I gloomily continued to rip and listen to Season Two of Sex and the City (kudos to my local library!). Eventually, I grew tired of it and tossed it aside. In retrospect, I suppose I gained valuable experience during my attempt at creating this sweater.

Last night in class, we discussed the assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter covers "implacement," while the second chapter explores "displacement." In the initial chapter, Casey argues that our modern world and culture are centered around time as the dominant force: we are constantly concerned with saving time, managing time, and being on time. However, he posits that focusing on place as the core of culture can foster a more rooted community. (I apologize for any oversimplification of the text in my summary, which is intended only to provide a brief overview.) Thus far, this book has been the first reading assignment that has truly captured my attention.

Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to give them those colors, there should be some sort of warning: they may make your life a bit unusual. And while laughter is beneficial, one wonders if we would have ended up on that fire escape drinking beer in the strong wind had we not consumed them earlier. Discovering ourselves in a doorway to a bar unfortunately closed for business, we halted to peruse an office-supplies catalog that had arrived in the mail. Fortunate we did. Who could have predicted that within these pages were the exceptional deals of a lifetime? Not I, certainly. I list just a few: purchase 36 permanent markers, receive a stunt kite. Acquire 30 lever arch files, obtain a grill.

Currently listening to: "The Little Drummer Boy" by Stevie Nicks ...and now my post... Senate Republicans, hands up – who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations marathon last week? I know I didn't. Well, okay – I did tune in briefly a couple of times. The entire extravagant waste of time was orchestrated by Republicans who, upset that Democrats wouldn't rubber-stamp four of Bush's controversial justice nominees, sought to score political points by staging a multiday spectacle. Never mind the fact that Democrats have already confirmed 168 of Bush's judicial appointments – no, that's not sufficient for the power-hungry Republicans who mistakenly believe they have a sweeping mandate for such shenanigans.

This was a satisfying weekend. I indulged in plenty of green tea, finally taking the time to enjoy some long overdue relaxation. I also made a point to catch up on some reading, finishing three engaging novels: Bruce Sterling's "Heavy Weather," Larry Niven's "World of Ptavvs," and Octavia Butler's "Parable of the Sower." "Heavy Weather" offered a thrilling cyberpunk adventure set in a dystopian future America, ravaged by climate change and societal collapse. Although it was intelligently crafted, well-paced, and thoroughly believable, I couldn't help but feel that something was missing in terms of emotional resonance. Don't get me wrong – the story and its characters were certainly well-developed and vividly rendered, but ultimately, it didn't leave a lasting impression on me. Perhaps my expectations were too high, but I can't help feeling that it fell short of being truly exceptional.

"The aftermath of the first week back from practicum was a struggle, but it's only in the second week that the full extent of the challenges has become apparent. Post-practicum trauma was a previously undiagnosed issue that is only now receiving attention. I was affected, but fortunately, the meeting with the course coordinator allowed me to share my concerns and prevent another student from experiencing a similarly difficult practicum placement. Just yesterday, I encountered an upset classmate who was adamant about warning a fellow student about the impending difficulties at her assigned school. I intervened and suggested we address our concerns with the administrator before taking any further action."

Well, things are incredibly busy here at times...but there's always time for supposed stress-relieving activities. I've discovered that I'm not skilled at 8-ball or ping pong! Rick (the Canadian) consistently defeats me in both games – we have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, so there's always time for a quick match. Last night, I took part in an 8-ball tournament held at the hot spot (our recreational tent equipped with a popcorn machine, multiple TVs, jukebox, DVD rentals, pool table, dartboard, and, of course, a ping pong table). Despite my initial success during the game, I ultimately scratched on the eight ball; it was quite disappointing (;(). Nevertheless, I still enjoyed myself – particularly when two Dutch soldiers joined the tournament, adding to the excitement.

Fall 1974: I was trying yet again - it felt like the thirteenth time - to work my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I have never been a fan of mathematics, and at that moment, I was certainly not in the mood for it. In fact, you could say I have a phobia of anything related to math. As I wrestled with algebraic equations, the doorbell rang. I set aside my book and answered the door, only to find no one there. Frustrating! I returned to my studies, determined to make progress, when suddenly, the doorbell rang again. Just like that, my fleeting moment of comprehension vanished. I opened the door once more, but found no one waiting outside. It seemed I had an unwelcome visitor who delighted in disrupting my already challenging mathematical journey.

This past week has been utterly draining. I spent Tuesday to Thursday completing the move to my new classroom. The larger space is conveniently located near my grade-level colleagues, which is a welcome change. However, the relocation consumed countless hours as I prepared the room for the upcoming academic year. In hindsight, had I known about the move before the end of the previous school year, I would have discarded unnecessary books and supplies, thus alleviating some of the burden. Regrettably, they accompanied me to the new room. Consequently, the week was spent moving, unpacking, and disposing of items with reckless abandon. My sincere gratitude goes out to Jill, a fellow teacher who assisted me immensely. She not only taught this month but also facilitated the transfer by having her students help move nearly all of my belongings from the old room!

You can't help it; you can't escape it: a part of you will forever reside within me. Even if we never had a child, were never married, or were never officially a couple... I cherished you deeply, and to this day, the emotion resonates through my being. Forever will I be reminded of those rare nights we shared together, our bodies and souls intertwined in a passionate embrace, enveloped in the salty darkness of an oceanfront evening... Or a kiss beneath the rainfall. Whenever I feel the sting of a shattered heart, you will be present. That fragment of you... Leaking the endless love that once flourished within me... And still persists. ... For her.

I'm uneasy. Investigative journalism feels misaligned to me. Let me rephrase that - the article I'm working on and its implications make me apprehensive. Maybe it's because I lack conviction in it, which hinders my ability to fully embrace the concept. The anxiety surrounding it. The unwavering dedication required to pursue it. Growing up in a nation where asking questions was discouraged has ingrained in me a wariness of exercising free speech. They imprison or even kill people for such inquiries. I'm still adjusting to this liberty of expression and the audacity to voice my doubts openly. While I may not be the most agreeable person, I aspire to become more confident in expressing myself.

We had an outing yesterday with my colleagues from the bank. We visited Guintubdan, La Carolina. It was a first-time experience for most of us. We hiked to the falls, which took around 30 minutes. We were all panting heavily. Whew! But we finally made it. The water was frigid; you could feel your body numbing due to the cold temperature. We spent less than an hour there before heading towards the neighboring waterfall, another 30-minute hike. However, the journey was rewarding since the cascade appeared serene, and the entire landscape was truly awe-inspiring. Immersing myself in the icy water felt like I was connecting with nature. The cool breeze and water were sufficient enough to lull me into a peaceful slumber.

"I'm confident that my sisters are intoxicated, given today's Pride celebrations in San Diego. I'm familiar with their drinking habits, and when it's time to imbibe, they certainly make the most of it. Unfortunately, I didn't inherit their love for drinking, which is a trait I attribute to their side of the family. There are only a handful of occasions when I feel like having a drink, and even then, it's not a frequent occurrence. With Ed set to leave in a month, it seems like the reality of the situation is finally setting in for both him and our family. Admittedly, it took me a while to come to terms with his departure, but now that we're nearing the end of his stay, I'm hoping he'll be able to remain until Bailey's surgery. We've been monitoring his swelling closely, and it's clear that there's quite a lot of fluid accumulation."

Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, thinking that the firemen's Easter egg hunt would begin at 11 am. As it happened, the event took place on Friday instead. Fortunately, I had brought a bag of eggs along, just in case. Connor thoroughly enjoyed searching for eggs throughout the park. On Sunday morning, he woke up thrilled that the Easter Bunny had visited. Seeing the joy on my child's face is truly priceless. Following the egg hunt, we attended church. Although the Easter Bunny may be entertaining, we ensure that our children understand the genuine significance behind the holidays. Incidentally, Megan experienced her first Easter this year, looking adorable in her denim dress and tights. The modifications made were minor and did not affect the sentence structure or order. The primary focus was on enhancing the accuracy, clarity, and suitability of the text by replacing certain words and phrases.

Friday, November 22, 2002 - Woohoo! My boots are at home! I accidentally had them delivered to my house instead of work, so now I have to wait four more hours to get them. Argh! They're the Faces boots and Tredair Flame boots. I'm thrilled! Unfortunately, I got a flat tire. Luckily, I'm at work, so my colleagues will inflate it for me and ensure it holds air. If not, they'll replace my tire with a new one. Fortunately, my spare tire is full-sized. I might purchase a new tire tonight - Hamad Tires, here I come! I mistakenly thought I found another VW.

I know in a previous post, I defended parents, almost taking their side. However, here's my change of heart. Parents are clueless. They think they know you so well, perhaps even believing they can read your emotions from your facial expressions. They cannot. Parents know next to nothing about us. When I went upstairs after arguing with Nicole about Kelli, as I did just a few minutes ago, and they asked me what was wrong, I felt like telling them to keep quiet. Why must I always reveal what's bothering me? Let me summarize the issue between Nicole and Kelli: they do not get along, period.

Music for the day: 94.7 FM. Almost didn't make it to work on time due to a massive accident at 14th and Constitution that has caused chaos on Virginia roads. Luckily, I was able to skillfully maneuver my car from the far left lane to the far right and eventually made it onto Route 50. Of course, this means little to those who don't reside in the area, so feel free to disregard. Nonetheless, I'm grateful to be seated here instead of being stuck in my vehicle. On a separate note, Sara decided to Google me yesterday, and much to my surprise, an email I sent to Ivan Maisel on ESPN.com was published online. I hadn't realized; I thought my argument could have been better written, but apparently, someone saw potential in it.

"Super duper mega ultimate raging blood decapitation beam slash hellfire Kamehameha blasts from my massive power Zoom Mech cannon, annihilating everything in its path. I'm bored. I'm really bored. I'm extremely bored. I'm incredibly bored. I'm unbelievably bored. I'm monumentally bored. I'm inconceivably bored. I'm astronomically bored. I'm fantastically bored. I'm impossibly bored. I'm mind-numbingly bored. My team and I sketched out some ideas earlier... it was amusing.... Gay frogs have nothing on my pole, which I'm currently using as a makeshift flagpole. I'm still bored."

"What can I say... Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban was absolutely brilliant! I went to see it immediately after school on Friday. Yes, that's right; I saw it on the opening day, thanks to Mike for the ticket. Daniel Radcliffe, also known as Harry Potter, has grown up so quickly and is quite adorable! Malfoy, too, haha. Anyway, the movie was truly excellent, and I give it 4 1/2 stars only because they omitted some significant details. Nevertheless, the film was enjoyable overall. I didn't dress up specifically for the movie, but I did wear a Ravenclaw tie, even though my preference lies with Gryffindor. I might go see the movie again in two more weeks."

"Pears and peanut butter attempt #2. This time, I have firm pears and my own jar of peanut butter, which I can dip the pears into. However, the peanut butter remains crunchy, not smooth, and I believe it makes a difference. Additionally, I'm somewhat dismayed to discover that this snack isn't as healthy as I thought, with approximately 614 calories per 100g, according to the label. I decided not to dwell on it. Earlier tonight, I visited my former music teacher and friend's home, where I recorded a taping of their performance. It was great seeing them again, albeit briefly, and I found out that Series 9 reruns air daily at 9:55 AM."

"The Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) has been invited by the State Department to observe the upcoming U.S. presidential election. The OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights will send a team of observers, marking the first time such a group has been present for a U.S. presidential vote. In contrast, a group of 13 Congressional Democrats, including four representatives from New York, have requested that United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan deploy international observers to Florida to monitor the voting process. However, based on available information, it appears that the OSCE's involvement is aimed at learning from the U.S. election process rather than overseeing it, as originally suggested by some partisan voices."

My foul mood has lifted. A tardy dosage of Prozac, coupled with forgetfulness, had rendered me sorrowful and tear-prone, Kristin. However, an unexpected visit from my boyfriend, followed by a shared ice cream sundae, and his comforting embrace after a distressing dream involving gunfire at a news bureau, contributed to my improved state. Although I don't have a work obligation this morning, I must contact a representative at KMIZ to obtain their rate card. This evening, I look forward to reunions with two cherished friends, Amy and Kate, ideally with sufficient time for studying between social engagements. Furthermore, there's a possibility of encountering a long-unseen acquaintance during our WW date tomorrow.

"A lot has been happening in my life lately... Debbie and I got into an argument over which china I could use. I mean, seriously, does one need that many expensive dishes for a gathering? She had an abundance of tableware: saucers, teapots, coffee cups, wine goblets, water glasses, seven different types of forks and spoons, dinner plates, salad plates, dessert plates, soup bowls, and side bowls... My reaction was utter disbelief! And then, she scolded me for snacking on appetizers while the turkey was cooking. My response was, "I'll eat, trust me!" Later, we visited my father in the hospital."

GOP gets scolded over recruitment at naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville; relocation planned. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville appeared to proceed normally, with a crowd of nearly 200 individuals becoming new Americans. As the new citizens prepared to leave the June 29 event, an immigration official overseeing the swearing-in encouraged them to visit a voter registration table—a common feature at naturalization ceremonies. However, this particular table was unusual, staffed by Republican volunteers who had pre-checked the party affiliation box, effectively registering all new voters as Republicans. This raised suspicions for Linda Cross, who attended the ceremony to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

"Hello everyone, I have some good news to share. Starting from next Monday, I will be taking over as PL for my project. My current PL is leaving for an onsite assignment two days from now, which is why I'm stepping in. I'll be working closely with two onsite coordinators and eight team members. At present, I'm busy finalizing our KT plans, as another project with a team of eight is set to assist us in the upcoming release, which promises to be quite significant. On Monday, we have a security audit scheduled in Chennai, Infosys. There are several details that need refining at this stage, but I'm confident that I can handle the responsibilities smoothly. Let's hope so! Wishing you all the best."

"It's not really a hooky day, but I've been accumulating spare days and decided to cash one in today, Wednesday, October 10th in Japan (the post time gives the U.S. date, so it's technically incorrect), so I can take a couple of days off and relax. Forty-eight hours of daydreaming should help me recharge my creative energy. As a foreigner, I have it relatively good, and my timing was fortunate. The illustration aspect is an added bonus. While I might grumble a bit if that hadn't fallen into my lap, I recognize that I'm still getting a raw deal. Still, I'm feeling peckish, so I might head over to Speak Easy, the American-style diner just across the street from the post office in my small prefecture, for some Mexican food."

I have always taken pride in ensuring that everyone who visits Casa Pescatore feels as comfortable as possible. I strive to create an atmosphere where guests feel at home, just like they would in their own residences. Yesterday, I believe I succeeded in doing so. A large crowd gathered on Perry Avenue, some with what might be considered extreme prejudice. At 4:30 pm, my close friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a generous portion of baked ziti. The tables were set, and I had prepared plenty of food, which led to the sound of clanging bells. Before I knew it, my dear friend from Florida, whom I had missed terribly, walked through the door, accompanied by his wife. Her presence was a lovely surprise, as she is expecting, and this was the closest I could get to being an uncle. I indulged her with plate after plate of delicious food and tiramisu.

I found the concept intriguing - perhaps it could have served as a means of escape from being branded a witch. As a non-American blogger, I have been hesitant to participate in certain discussions, especially those surrounding flags. However, now that I have broached the topic, I feel compelled to express my thoughts. Initially, I believe that the notion of enacting legislation prohibiting flag-burning is utterly absurd. By granting a symbol - any symbol - such automatic veneration and safeguarding, one takes a subtle yet significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently ephemeral - their meanings are not innate but rather derived from how they are perceived and utilized by individuals.

"Prom is tomorrow... I hope it's going to be fun. That's all I ask. Rob arrives on May 14th... Yeah, three weeks from today.... Oh God, I think I'm giving myself an ulcer just thinking about it. But I'm really excited to see him, although I'm also pretty nervous. The Leafs played last night, but since Calgary was playing at the same time and I'm located on the West Coast, I had to watch the Calgary game instead of the Leafs game. That's okay, I guess... considering my Leafs lost, which makes me sad. But Philly is a great team, so... I still have bragging rights. They went further than the Canucks did!"

"Okay, so I haven't seen what my blog will look like yet. But supposedly, this is where I should begin. I'm uncertain about what will happen here; whether I'll take to it or not, but since I spend a significant amount of time in front of a screen, I might as well utilize it properly and share these fleeting thoughts that wander aimlessly in my mind. I was inspired by a blogger whom I've never met personally, who managed to keep her readers informed about her daily life in an engaging and entertaining way..."

"Everyone has their favorite movie or series of movies; mine happens to be the Evil Dead franchise. It shouldn't come as a surprise, given my impressive collection of memorabilia from the series. Do I play an instrument? Indeed, I do - the bass guitar, which I enthusiastically strum to express my musical inclinations. My biggest financial indulgence? Either my penchant for amassing DVDs or my tendency to stay up-to-date with the latest technological advancements. Any irrational fears, allergies, or habitual behaviors? None that I can think of, but I do feel compelled to arrange the bills in my wallet in ascending order from smallest to largest at all times. Now, let me ask you: how much wood could a woodchuck potentially move if it were capable of chucking wood? Well, I suppose it's impossible to say, but I'm willing to bet it would be quite considerable."

"I saw Troy tonight with my family...I wasn't impressed. I'm too exhausted to delve deeply into specifics, but I believe it had promise. However, I think too much effort was devoted to the set (which was spectacular) and not enough to establishing a cohesive tone, theme, etc. It retold the story, but it didn't captivate me, and I don't feel like I took away anything meaningful from watching it. The character development was relatively lacking. Furthermore, I found the score to be subpar and eerily reminiscent of Gladiator. Gladiator effectively employed background music featuring a mournful woman's voice, which enhanced and complemented a truly engrossing narrative."

Urllink invites us all to greet the latest RDF/RSS reader on the scene, Urllink Pulpfiction 1.0, freshly developed by Urllink Software. Judging by its features, it appears to possess an abundance of native application advantages. Worth mentioning is that it doesn't come for free, nor is it open-source, given the current debate surrounding these issues. You may test it for 15 days before deciding whether to purchase it for $25 or switch to another option. One notable aspect is how each entry functions independently, allowing users to organize, label, delete, or move them freely. This flexibility will undoubtedly appeal to those who closely follow news feeds. Additionally, it supports seamless importing and exporting of OPML files, just as we would anticipate.

Today, I miss my sister dearly – it feels odd not having her around, even though she could be annoying at times (just kidding!). Despite only being away for a week, she certainly left her mark, and I mean that in a positive way. Working on our Tasmania scrapbook brings back pleasant memories of recent times – specifically, last week. Perhaps it's the thought of not seeing her for an extended period that's getting to me; she's off to Bristol in September and October, you see. My sister symbolized, on a deeper level, a connection to my family back home. How I long for them all. Tomorrow marks the beginning of a fresh academic term. Can you believe how quickly the holidays flew by?

"Have you ever had one of those days when you couldn't quite put your finger on what was bothering you? Like, you knew something was off, but couldn't quite articulate it? No? Well, then you can stop reading now, as the rest of this won't make much sense to you. But for those of you who choose to continue, I'll share an observation: Sometimes, I wish I'd been given a manual. A good manual, that is. One that provides clear instructions on what each thing does, how it works, and what to do when things go awry. You know, like the kind of manual that comes with a new appliance or electronics device. That way, I could simply consult the manual instead of scratching my head, wondering what Button X or Y does, or why things aren't working as intended. Alas, no such luck. I didn't come with a manual."

The spreadsheet below displays the implied commodity cost based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (Schedule DR). "Magic fans beware... Wizards is reluctant to create a quality digital game. At its essence, Magic: The Gathering is a social experience meant to be enjoyed with friends (or rivals) while having fun, trash-talking, and pulling off game-winning moves. Unfortunately, Wizards of the Coast appears to have overlooked this aspect. When playing with friends, you cannot earn gold, which is a vital component since it unlocks various in-game features. While there is a daily cap on gold earnings, this limitation is reasonable given that gold allows players to access all game content. However, prepare for an arduous and solitary 1v1 grind against AI opponents or strangers if you prefer not to spend money. Unlocking cards through free play requires approximately four hours of dedicated time per day for several weeks."

Being the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the negative aspects first. I dislike prequels because they move the story backward instead of forward, which can be problematic (a concern applicable to all prequels). However, it does offer more depth to the narrative. The combat feels clumsy and lacks the precision that Arkham City achieved. As of my writing this recommendation (October 26, 2013), a game-breaking bug prevents a side mission from completion (although the main story remains unaffected). Additionally, some gadgets are assigned to an inconvenient keybind that requires an excessive amount of finger movement across the keyboard, potentially disrupting combos during combat.

They essentially fixed Shadow Warrior (2013), that is, the boss battles are impressive, the weaponry feels satisfying (although perhaps not as exceptional as D44M's arsenal), and the adversaries don't feel excessively durable (provided you're adept at managing elements and upgrades). The upgrade mechanism is well-balanced, and once mastered, it's not overly tiresome. The incorporation of elemental aspects and limited ammunition encourages the use of diverse armaments, adding variety to combat. The game features an array of singular, practical firearms that remain useful throughout the game, setting it apart from Borderlands' formulaic 'rng' weaponry. Accompanying the engaging gameplay is superb sound design, highlighted by an outstanding main theme and Stan Bush's memorable tracks.

"So many things have gone wrong. I don't even know where to begin with this review. This all refers to my career. My player is an outside scorer, a point guard, 1.71 meters tall, with maximized statistics and all necessary perks. Now, let me ask you, why does shooting ability depend on height? Why can someone who is 1.74 meters tall not become as skilled at shooting as someone who is 1.71 meters tall? In real life, I am 1.87 meters tall, and I created my first player with this height, only to discover that I couldn't achieve a skill level higher than 89. That's blatant discrimination! And why didn't the game inform me of this limitation before I created my character, or even when I reached the skill limit after weeks of playtime?!"

I believe Assassin's Creed has perfected its mechanics across the board (ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, etc.). I found myself particularly attached to this protagonist, and the story, though initially rough, significantly improves as the game progresses (a common trait among AC games, in my opinion). Edward and the supporting cast are intriguing characters, and I appreciated how the various collectibles genuinely contributed to the gameplay experience, offering a sense of accomplishment without feeling obligatory. The rewards were also well-balanced, making the process of acquiring them enjoyable.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't entirely terrible. The gunplay is adequate, provided you have the funds to purchase gun parts, which is my primary gripe with this game: it's pay-to-win. If I could look past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is entertaining to use, and HRV is a great concept. I would choose this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction model is a turnoff for me. If you're comfortable with this model, then by all means, enjoy yourself. However, if you share my distaste for pay-to-win games, then it's best to pass on this one; it's not our cup of tea.

"While not flawless, this game has been thoroughly enjoyable. The save system and risk of unexpected death have led to occasional frustration, particularly when I lost my primary character during my initial playthrough around the 10-hour mark. A save-and-reload feature would have been helpful then. To mitigate such issues, I've adopted a third-party mod/save tool. Additionally, the aiming reticle could be larger, and the zoom function slightly stronger. Despite these minor drawbacks, the game has been an absolute delight. As someone who doesn't typically enjoy zombie-themed games, the mix of strategic elements, missions, first-person shooting, and beat 'em up mechanics has captivated me. I find myself playing it every chance I get... eager for just one more mission, one more supply run, or simply seeking safety before exiting the game."

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every other wargame (European Escalation and AlB), I have to say this one stands out. The sheer number of units available is impressive. While I'm unsure of the exact count, rest assured there are plenty – a veritable plethora, even! The graphics are breathtaking, the sound design is top-notch, and the gameplay is truly epic. Even the in-game chatbox at the main menu provides entertainment, believe me. However, don't let its appeal fool you; this game is by no means a walk in the park. If you're new to the strategy genre or underestimate its difficulty, prepare to invest significant time mastering its intricacies. You'll undoubtedly lose numerous units along the way, so always plan ahead, maintain adequate anti-air and anti-tank capabilities, and adapt your strategies accordingly.

I had a negative bias towards this game before playing it. I wasn't even sure about purchasing it. The concept of portal guns and portals seemed strange to me, despite my fondness for science fiction. However, I couldn't have been more mistaken. The humor and voice acting in this game are truly outstanding. While some parts may be slightly cheesy, it's generally well-executed and never feels forced. Each character has a distinct personality, which adds depth and variety to the gameplay experience. Additionally, the level design is superb - clever, challenging, and visually appealing. Incidentally, I never played the first Portal game until after completing its sequel. Now, I plan to play it when I find the time. If I hadn't experienced the second installment, I likely wouldn't have tried the original either.

"Let's start with the pros (+) and cons (-) before sharing my thoughts on this game. The pros include some of the best characters, a good story, loads of content, customizable character options (you can choose to be male or female), and the ability to have relationships with most of your companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest). However, there are also some cons, such as bad graphics (although I don't think they're a deal-breaker), awkward and weird love scenes, invisible walls, and a boring mission (but everyone has different tastes). One thing to note is that your protagonist cannot speak, which may be a drawback for some players. Overall, I love this game and believe it's one of the best RPGs or games in general that I've ever played. If you're an RPG fan, you probably already have this game."

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who recall (at least in the UK) watching the annoying Timmy Mallett simply for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus Prime, Megatron, Bumblebee, and numerous others have returned, and their voices are immediately recognizable. The iconic cartoon transformation sound is also present. Visually, the cel-shaded presentation is flawless, and perfectly captures the spirit of Generation One. However, aside from its nostalgic appeal, the game is genuinely enjoyable. The combat mechanics are exceptionally well-executed, with transforming mid-fight often being necessary and seamlessly integrated into combinations, setting it apart from High Moon's superb War for/Fall of Cybertron games. Notably, melee combat plays a significant role in the gameplay, though certain foes (such as Seekers) necessitate switching to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it for a brief period, and it was underwhelming. I spent more time attempting to log in than actually playing the game due to a persistent bug. Every time I clicked "accept" after being prompted to agree to an updated terms of service agreement, the message would simply reappear. Restarting the client was necessary to resolve the issue. While this wasn't too bothersome, I questioned the necessity of linking my Steam and GFace accounts. Although the company claimed it was for DLC purposes, I found it hard to understand why this was required. Furthermore, once linked, the connection couldn't be undone, leaving me uneasy about a company I had no interest in having access to my Steam information. As for the game itself, it was unremarkable and blatantly inspired by Call of Duty. Somehow, the developers managed to make the gunplay inferior...a feat that seemed nearly impossible.

"4K resolution at 60 frames per second (GTX 970), dual audio options, and Neptune Gear inclusion - what's not to love? Check out the excellent port and great entry point to the series here: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo>. While there is some skippable dialogue, I found the gameplay enjoyable with both keyboard-and-mouse and gamepad setups, both of which are fully rebindable. At its price point, I wouldn't have hesitated to purchase it, especially considering over half of the DLC is included for free, offering plenty of content to explore. This game comes highly recommended to JRPG, anime, and visual novel enthusiasts who don't mind occasional breaks in the action. For those interested, I've also created a no-commentary playlist: <https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLSlsFVIJAUpsZeZ9aF395MVNK63xnHSJ1_>."

I encountered no performance issues even at launch, and after all these patches, it runs smoothly. In my opinion, this is an excellent and entertaining game, despite some minor annoyances with the format (specifically, the free-roaming city area respawning new enemies as you advance through the narrative). The "dual play" sections, where I could play as Batman accompanied by another character, were especially engaging. Additionally, having the option to utilize a controller for most parts of the game while switching to mouse and keyboard controls during tank combat sequences was much appreciated. Steering the Batmobile throughout the open city, including during APC commander pursuits, became genuinely enjoyable once I learned how to effectively brake and drift around corners. With practice, navigating the city became truly delightful!

"Damn fine FPS shooter – that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays great, with excellent FPS mechanics, an engaging story, memorable characters, seamless voice acting, and an epic soundtrack. However, it's not for the faint of heart, as some of the cutscenes can be quite graphic and intense. While the game is superb overall, there are a few noticeable flaws: lack of SLI support (which forced me to upgrade my GPU), and occasionally, trivial obstacles that prove impossible to climb. To fully enjoy the experience, make sure your GPU is up to par."

"English is not my native language; I am Dutch. Please disregard any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this excellent game. I will break down my assessment into several categories: graphics, controls, sound, gameplay, replayability, and overall experience. The graphics are stunning, utilizing a comic-book style that is both visually appealing and well-suited for the game's genre. The visuals are sleek, with no unnecessary details, and feature nice color schemes. Even on high settings, the game runs smoothly on my system, which includes an Intel Core i5 processor and NVIDIA GeForce GT 710M graphics card with 8GB of RAM, under Windows 8.1. In terms of controls, the game offers versatility by being playable with either a keyboard and mouse or an Xbox controller."

"You can see by the hours I've put into this game that I truly enjoy it. It's everything I had hoped a search game from COD would be. However, don't buy this game expecting it to be similar to COD, Battlefield, or any other first-person shooter. It's a unique game in its own right and should be treated as such. I can't count the number of times I've heard new players complaining about getting killed quickly. Good grief, people! Getting shot in the face and dying is part of the experience. It's not like it doesn't happen in real life, you know? Besides, it's not like CS:GO is the only great multiplayer game out there. Give this one a try when you need a break from that."

I've been playing for two hours now and am thoroughly enjoying myself. The gameplay is engaging, the art design is stunning, the music is impressively good, and the storyline has piqued my interest. The puzzles are entertaining as well. However, what truly sets this game apart is its comedic value. Fans of RPGs since their inception will find themselves chuckling at the numerous jokes, parodies, and nods to classic games. Even those new to the genre can appreciate the humor. Final Fantasy 7 or X veterans, in particular, owe it to themselves to try this out – but I won't spoil the surprises. After just two hours, I needed to take a break to give my face a rest from all the smiling and laughing. This game has been a true delight so far."

I apologize sincerely, as I strive to be supportive of free-to-play games and independent developers. However, I must admit that I did not enjoy this particular title. The game's description seemed tailored to my preferences, but unfortunately, its execution fell short. As an enthusiast of puzzle and exploration games, I found the experience to be counterintuitive, and even after referring to tutorials, I failed to discover any enjoyment in the gameplay. Moreover, the absence of a pause button was glaring, especially given the time-sensitive nature of many in-game sequences. Additionally, I felt that the game consisted of an excessive amount of cutscenes, leaving me idle for extended periods.

"This game... wow, where do I even begin? It was utterly captivating, with a story that drew me in from the start and graphics that were simply stunning. The narrative wasn't just a shallow excuse for gameplay; it genuinely felt like I was experiencing the events unfold as the protagonist, eager to uncover the mystery that drove the plot forward. The gameplay itself was engaging, and I must admit that I discovered a newfound fear of heights thanks to the ice caverns! Despite my trepidation, I persevered for Uncle Fred's sake, and I'm glad I did. If you developers create a DLC or sequel, I'll be the first in line to purchase it and recommend it to all my friends. Kudos to everyone involved in crafting this masterpiece – you've created an unforgettable gaming experience."

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based strategy game in which players build their civilizations towards a specific objective or "victory." Unlike previous titles in the series, which followed a linear progression through historical eras like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age, this game takes place in the future and involves colonizing a new planet. One aspect I appreciate about Beyond Earth is how 2K Games introduced fresh mechanics, such as the affinity system and orbital layer, which add depth and complexity to gameplay. However, I found the sheer number of new features somewhat overwhelming at times. An area where the game could be further refined is by incorporating more varied environmental artwork, particularly during diplomatic interactions with other leaders, to enhance the visual appeal and immersion.

"Great game! Tons of replayability and a very enjoyable zombie survival experience! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. After clocking over 60 hours, I can confidently say that this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games out there. It's designed like a true survival horror experience, where you must conserve your ammunition, tend to your wounds when you're injured, and take medication when infected. The zombies also have a natural, lifelike animation, which is impressive for a free-to-play game. Additionally, while playing with friends is recommended, the community is friendly and welcoming, making it easy to strike up conversations and form new friendships through chat or voice comms."

"February 7, 2014 - It's a shame I can't wholeheartedly recommend or enjoy this game, given the short time I've played it, I know I'd be hooked if it weren't for the following two issues. Lack of Australian servers means a single red bar puts me at a significant disadvantage, resulting in unbearable lag. Ironically, even the offline training mode stutters and lags (how is that possible?). Combine that with poor ping, and it utterly spoils the experience. Additionally, everything artifacts excessively – menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game elements. I've never encountered this problem with this graphics card before, so I thought it might not appreciate my overclocking attempts. However, reverting my GPU to its stock settings made no difference."

Last night, I finally completed the game. While the narrative may lack depth and intrigue, the storytelling technique utilized throughout the game sets it apart. The richly detailed atmosphere immerses players, and the numerous collectibles effectively flesh out the world of Batman. Although the game features only a handful of boss battles, they provide an enjoyable challenge. However, leveling up Batman feels underwhelming. Fortunately, upgrading and acquiring various gadgets introduces fresh gameplay mechanics, adding variety to the experience. Unlocking access to previously inaccessible areas also provides a strong sense of progress.

"'To the Moon' is no ordinary game; it's an immersive experience, and one of the most memorable experiences I've had. While TellTale's 'The Walking Dead' may be emotionally taxing, 'To the Moon' surpasses it in both sorrow and satisfaction. I've never felt such a deep emotional connection to a fictional narrative. This masterpiece represents the epitome of storytelling, complemented by a beautiful and enchanting soundtrack. Although the controls can be finicky, and the gameplay isn't the main draw, the captivating tale more than makes up for it. Additionally, the game's humor is delightful and doesn't detract from the story's sophistication. The numerous Doctor Who references are also a treat."

Bastion is a bloodily brilliant game, boasting a truly captivating storyline. Set in a world recovering from some cataclysmic event, you embark on a mission to rebuild and fortify your stronghold, known as the Bastion. The game offers an impressive array of choices, allowing you to strategize and tailor your playstyle according to your preferences. You can choose which structures to construct, each granting unique advantages; select from a diverse arsenal of weapons, each with its own distinct attributes and upgrade paths; and opt for various potions and elixirs that imbue your weapons with temporary bonuses. The game's vibrant art style and enthralling soundtrack are also noteworthy, injecting a burst of color and life into the post-apocalyptic landscape. Moreover, the game features dynamic narration that adapts to your actions, ensuring that the commentary remains contextually relevant and engaging. For instance, if you decide to swap out one weapon for another in the armory, the narrator will seamlessly acknowledge your decision and incorporate it into their dialogue.

I had originally purchased this game during its early development phase, when the only currency was Spacebux and there was no "tech tree." At that time, the game was enjoyable. All weapons were similarly overpowered, which meant that there were no balance issues; anyone could defeat anyone else at any moment. Additionally, the game provided players with an unlimited number of gun slots and five loadouts. Considering the game boasted "bajillions of guns," it seemed reasonable to expect more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before having to pay for additional upgrades. In fact, I had accumulated nearly three full pages of weapons and was brainstorming new ideas for more, as that aspect of the game was particularly engaging for me.

This game proved to be a hidden gem. Frequently, product reviews can be deceiving, but in this instance, they accurately reflect the entertainment value of this unique game. It seamlessly blends elements of traditional 2D platformers and MOBAs, doing so with flair. I found myself drawn to characters that I typically wouldn't enjoy in other MOBAs. Despite my initial reservations, I opted to try a melee tank character, and the experience exceeded my expectations. I continued to experiment with different characters as they became available through gameplay progression. The game's visual style and user interface have an endearing quality to them. As a result, I've adopted one of the characters as my avatar and even created a card set featuring artwork from the game.

I recently began playing, and I'm thoroughly enjoying this game. I don my headphones and become completely immersed in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had such a profound impact on me. The music sets the tone perfectly, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are intuitive and responsive. I eagerly anticipate each combat encounter, and the developers have done an excellent job optimizing them. My initial reservations about the naval combat system were quickly dispelled, as it's tremendously entertaining to decimate multiple fleets simultaneously. The only way to falter in this game is to neglect to retreat when necessary. If the situation appears dire, a swift exit, regrouping, and counterattack are key. Kudos, developers, for creating an exceptional gaming experience!

The revamp of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about numerous changes, especially for the series' protagonist, Dante. Although fans of the original series may feel disenchanted by the transformation of their beloved character, it's undoubtedly for the better. This latest installment by Ninja Theory serves as an ideal entry point for newcomers to the series, showcasing the genesis of a conceited and cynical Dante and tracing his metamorphosis from skepticism to selflessness. The game skillfully crafts a distinct narrative arc for the updated Dante, making him a captivating figure to follow. Imagine the tale unfolding as Dante is drawn into a degenerate world he had deliberately ignored.

"Where do I even begin with this incredible game? Its story is utterly captivating. The level of detail put into it is astounding, and it's a mix of pure joy, clever puns, and occasional frustration. It knows when to be serious and when to inject humor. The character design is superb, boasting diverse personalities and hidden secrets. What sets it apart from other RPGs is the fact that you don't have to kill anyone, a refreshing twist in the genre. Drawing inspiration from EarthBound, one of the greatest RPGs ever made, it's clear that this game is something special. The soundtrack is simply breathtaking, hands down the best I've heard in ages."

I am recommending this solely due to its lack of cost, and it may provide a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my personal experience, the "game" failed to have an impact on me. Relying heavily on shock value, it did not evoke any emotional response from me. Perhaps I have become desensitized, or maybe the content was too simplistic to elicit a reaction. The second half of the game attempts to create a visual representation (literally) of a person experiencing mental deterioration. It explores themes such as obsession, hallucinations, depression, and others. While the concept is intriguing, the "game" took me only 10 minutes to complete, including reading and thoroughly examining all available information.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that presents a concept and then lets you figure it out for yourself. It's an incredible way to challenge your mind while still being enjoyable. Although this game doesn't have a strong narrative, it did spawn one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play it and beat it when I'm feeling bored, and I love returning to it to see where a legend was born and what made it legendary. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is straightforward, to say the least. You utilize portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate parts of the puzzle. There are two types of buttons in the game: ones you press manually and others that require a cube to trigger.

"If you can ignore the few bugs (I encountered only two, one minor and the other somewhat frustrating), I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone seeking a space exploration experience. Most reviews focus on system specifications, so here are mine: Intel Core i5 6600K (approximately €200), Radeon RX480 (€200), Z170 Pro Gaming motherboard (€150), and 16GB DDR4 RAM (€70). While not exactly budget-friendly at around €650, it's well within the mid-range category. With VSYNC enabled, I consistently achieved frame rates above 60 FPS on high graphics settings – unbelievable compared to the majority of comments claiming superior setups but struggling with subpar performance."

Remember Age of Mythology? It's been that long since we've seen an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes remarkably close to the boundaries of my personal favorite RTS game. Pair this with a substantial risk-like grand strategy mode, and it hits the mark. I strive not to be biased simply because this game enables you to transform into a dragon, assisting your troops by supporting, attacking, and even directing unit production, movement, and spawn points simultaneously. While I appreciate intricate RTS games like Civilization V, they often burden players with convoluted mechanics, cluttered interfaces, and excessive resource management. In contrast, Divinity: Dragon Commander strikes a balance between depth and accessibility.

Undertale coheres to create an experience greater than the sum of its components. The graphics are effective for a retro title, and the music is pleasing, but when combined, they produce moments that are both visually and aurally stunning. The writing covers a wide range, from humorous to poignant to devastating to uplifting, often simultaneously, and subverts RPG conventions in the process. The game's narrative, characters, and mechanics are equally captivating, and I could easily expound upon them at length. Instead, I'll simply advise: if you enjoy RPGs, play this game; if you appreciate video games, play this game; and if you have seven hours to spare before your demise, play this game.

If you enjoyed Witcher 1 and 2, Witcher 3 is a must-play. I would typically give this game a 10/10 rating, but unfortunately, since updating to version 1.03, it has become somewhat buggy, with frequent crashes and random issues. Therefore, it's essential to save frequently. In contrast, during my playthrough from version 1.00 to 1.03, the game was stable, and I didn't encounter any significant problems. However, I have noticed that after installing the 1.03 patch, the drawing distance can be terrible at times, only displaying objects or characters when you're very close. Despite these technical issues, the game remains exceptional, with a tremendous amount of effort put into creating engaging quests, many of which offer profound and emotional experiences. There are also numerous side quests, and your choices significantly impact the game's outcome. After playing for over 50 hours, I'm still eager to continue exploring its vast world.

I have only owned this game for a brief period, but in that short time, two DLCs have been released, accompanied by patches that have enhanced an already exceptional gaming experience. The developers maintain a strong presence in the community, engaging in various discussions and sharing insights through dev diaries. While there is a somewhat challenging learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I am still navigating, the depth of strategy offers numerous approaches to achieving objectives and capitalizing on situational opportunities. In my opinion, the game boasts near-infinite replayability, as each session draws me in and keeps me engaged, regardless of its progress.

Warframe is an enjoyable game for the first few hours of play. However, after those initial hours, you may find that the game's combat, enemies, and gameplay become repetitive. Despite this, the developers actively update the game with significant changes to its systems, new warframes, and various tweaks and features. While it's a good game to play casually, it may not hold your attention beyond a few months, especially if you don't enjoy grinding. On the bright side, the game is free, so I would still recommend giving it a try. If you're seeking a quick gaming fix, consider checking out Warframe.

This game is incredibly dull. I purchased it under the assumption that it was a PC version of "Katamari Damacy," a well-liked and enjoyable PS2 game. Unfortunately, it falls short of my expectations. The game involves absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb even more massive items. However, the gameplay is not as polished as it could be, and the levels lack creativity. Moreover, the experience is a bleak and unsettling horror show, leaving me questioning the value of existence. Every living creature in the game, ranging from tiny pets to humans, raises suspicions about the developers' fascination with taxidermy.

"As someone deeply interested in politics, I was excited to learn about this game. Initially, I thought, 'Wow, a simulator of the path to the presidency? That sounds enjoyable!' However, my enthusiasm quickly waned when I realized that the game forces players to choose between Republican and Democratic parties, with no option for independents or third-party candidates. Despite this disappointment, I decided to continue playing to see what else the game had to offer. One aspect that surprised me was the character customization feature, which allowed me to create a unique appearance for my candidate. Although the options were somewhat limited, it was amusing to play around with them. Notably, it was the only time during the game where I had the freedom to choose whether or not to wear a hat."

The storyline of Fallout 3 was superior. Settlement management often interferes with the narrative, making it feel like babysitting instead of enjoying the gameplay experience. Certain controls cannot be remapped, which can be frustrating, and there are numerous bugs present in the game. At one point, my Pip-Boy vanished, and I had to resort to console commands to retrieve it. Power armor is readily available early on and abundant in traders' shops, rendering its value less significant compared to previous titles. While the game's stability is an improvement over Fallout 3, its overall quality falls short of expectations. Despite not being as good as New Vegas either, this installment has been excessively hyped.

My statistics at the time of writing this review: * 8.6 hours to complete
* 10 collectibles found out of 25
* Zero achievements out of 15 What I enjoyed: * Visuals up until the final level (ice caves) were impressive
* Although the story was not exceptional, the ending (post-credits scene) somewhat made up for the time spent playing the game What I didn't like: * Underwhelming visuals in the final level
* Gameplay in the last level became significantly more challenging, leading to a frustrating experience of repeated attempts before succeeding
* Achievements were excessively difficult, with only less than 2.1% of players managing to unlock 13 out of 15 The revisions aimed to enhance the clarity and suitability of the text while maintaining the original sentence structure. Some of the key changes include: 1. Replaced "stats" with "statistics" to use a more appropriate term.
2.

Pros: +graphics
Cons: -glitches (particularly environmental issues that cause players to become stuck or prevent them from hitting enemies despite having a clear line of sight) -overly simplistic AI -enemies exhibit unrealistically keen awareness of the player's location once they have been spotted -frustratingly accurate enemy aim reminiscent of the first Ghost Warrior game -poor checkpoint system and save feature -unengaging narrative that fails to capture the reader's interest, making the gameplay experience feel tedious and unrewarding. I would only recommend purchasing this game at a steep discount of 90% or higher, as completing it feels more like a chore than an enjoyable pastime. Even then, I question whether it's worth investing time into something so lackluster, especially considering the disappointment I experienced with the previous title in the series.

"Do not purchase this game until further notice; the servers are currently offline, making it unplayable. As I mentioned earlier, while I was able to play it, I thoroughly enjoyed it, much like the classic tune by the Steve Miller Band... 'Take the Money and Run.' However, my enthusiasm for the game has been dampened by the numerous issues plaguing it, including overpowered weapons and questionable matchmaking that often pits new players against experienced ones, leading to frustrating experiences. In addition, the game's current state is reminiscent of Battlefield 3, where matchmaking would frequently pair low-level players with high-level players, resulting in an uneven playing field."

Who wouldn't want to don a fez? This delightful puzzle-platformer stars a diminutive hero sporting a fez, as he gatherings tiny fragments to construct a cube and traverses an extensive, labyrinthine landscape. The game offers considerable hilarity, and completing it was an enjoyable experience. However, obtaining every cube and accomplishment can become mildly vexing, as you'll need to decipher cryptic codes. These may require a mere moment's thought or lead to utter frustration, prompting you to consult a walkthrough (I reluctantly raised my hand and sought guidance). The comprehensive manual, titled "Fez: A Complete Guide," provides valuable assistance.

It's not difficult for me to understand why others enjoy this game, but it didn't quite suit my tastes. Firstly, I own a Vive and prefer playing room-scale games with motion controllers. Moreover, while the game's vast universe was initially breathtaking, I found that same scope to be a detriment to my enjoyment. The steep learning curve and substantial time investment required at the outset made it challenging for me to fully engage with the experience. If I had more patience and dedicated gaming time, perhaps this title would hold greater appeal. However, given my limited availability and abundance of alternative VR games that interest me, I'll stick with other options.

Hands down, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun rambo wannabes need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistically depicted. A single hit to the chest, neck, or head from a rifle-caliber weapon usually results in death, unless it merely grazes you. Rounds drop over distance, and controlled bursts are necessary to stay on target. There's no infinite ammo pool. Reloading mid-magazine means you'll have a pouch full of partial mags. You can't sprint indefinitely; after a brief dash, your aim will falter as you struggle to catch your breath. To stabilize your aim, rest your weapon on your elbows when prone or on a windowsill. Standing compromises accuracy.

"Let me begin by stating that I didn't purchase EU when it was first released, and I acquired it during a sale that included EW. Consequently, I didn't experience the issues that some people claim to have had with the game. In fact, I thoroughly enjoyed it, although it was quite challenging in the early stages. However, the sense of accomplishment I felt when I completed tasks correctly made up for the difficulty. Moving on to XCOM2, I must say that I'm also enjoying it. The game runs fairly smoothly on my GTX560 with 2GB VRAM, albeit with a few initial hiccups. Initially, the game defaulted to high settings, causing some slowdown, but reducing the settings to medium resolved the issue. It's worth mentioning that I've been fortunate when it comes to encountering issues with games; perhaps others who have had problems are simply more vocal about their experiences."

"Listen, this game is a blast. Despite some drawbacks, such as a limited selection of equipment and levelling skills, there's still plenty of variety and strategy to explore. The game gets off to a quick start and maintains its momentum. Even with a relatively small number of equipment options, there's always a new ship to unlock or skill to master. Mods are key to extending the game's lifespan; "Fight for Universe" stands out as particularly excellent, while "Big Fight for Beef" is also noteworthy."

World leaders convene to address uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political leaders from across the globe arrive in Davos, Switzerland for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will deliberate on various issues, including China's economic influence, Iraq's future following Sunday's elections, and other pressing concerns. Among the attendees are Prime Minister Tony Blair of the UK and President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, along with some 20 other government leaders and heads of state. Notably, this year's WEF has not drawn the usual anti-globalization protests, with activists cancelling a previously planned demonstration. Instead, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the alternative World Social Forum, scheduled to coincide with the WEF's exclusive gathering in Davos.

Deadline looms for Fiat-GM deal
Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on February 1st to resolve a dispute over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its automotive division to GM, as part of an alliance established in 2000. GM, whose European operations are struggling financially, no longer wishes to acquire the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of stalled negotiations sent Fiat's shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, following Monday's 4% surge on expectations of a settlement. The US company is believed to be offering approximately $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to exit the agreement. It has claimed that Fiat's decision to divest its financial arm and reduce GM's stake through a capital increase rendered the deal null and void. The 2000 agreement was the result of a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to form an alliance with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticized the Iraq War, stating that the billions of pounds spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East could have been better used to alleviate poverty. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales made the comment during an interview on BBC Radio 4 and plans to reiterate his position during his Christmas midnight mass. In his Christmas message, the cardinal described the war as a "tragic" waste of resources. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have publicly expressed their disapproval of the war. During his appearance on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day segment, the cardinal lamented the fact that vast sums have been devoted to military efforts rather than addressing issues of extreme poverty, malnutrition, and illness. He urged that 2005 be the year for advocating to "end poverty."

British stars were shut out of major Oscar categories, dashing UK hopes for acting and directing honors. Despite three nods, Mike Leigh's Vera Drake did not secure Director or Screenplay awards, and Imelda Staunton went home empty-handed. Kate Winslet fell short in the Best Actress race, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo missed out on Supporting Actor statuettes. However, the UK's Andrea Arnold scored a victory in the Short Film category with her gritty drama Wasp. Arnold, who previously hosted children's TV shows Number 73 and Motormouth in the 1980s, described the win as "completely overwhelming." Wasp, which depicts the struggles of a poverty-stricken single mother, triumphed over entries from fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Halloween screenwriter and producer Debra Hill passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54 after battling cancer. Hill is best known for her work on the 1978 horror classic Halloween, which she co-wrote with John Carpenter, who also directed the film. The movie stars Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter tormented by a psychopath and went on to gross over $60 million worldwide, setting a record for independent films at the time. In addition to Halloween, Hill collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. A trailblazing woman in film, Hill started her career as a production assistant and worked her way up to become an assistant director and second-unit director before teaming up with Carpenter.

Broadband fosters online expression; fast web access is prompting increasing numbers of individuals to share their thoughts and ideas digitally, studies suggest. In Britain, approximately one-quarter of broadband users frequently upload content and maintain personal websites, as indicated by a report published by the UK think tank Demos. The organization discovered that continuous, rapid connectivity is transforming internet utilization patterns. Over five million British households have adopted broadband, a figure that continues to rise rapidly. The Demos study examined how broadband affects internet habits and found that over half of broadband subscribers go online before breakfast, while nearly one-fifth confessed to browsing the web during late-night hours.
