Most notably, the report highlights that broadband empowers users to engage more actively online.

Yukos heads back to US courts as Russian oil and gas company fights for survival. Yukos is set to appear in a US court on Thursday as it continues its battle against forced liquidation. The Russian government seeks to dissolve the company and seize its assets to cover a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax debt. In an effort to prevent this, Yukos has filed for bankruptcy protection in the US, invoking international business laws to forestall the sale of its primary oil production asset, Yuganskneftegas. Despite these efforts, the unit was sold to state-owned Rosneft for $9.4 billion during a controversial auction that was marred by disruptions. Yukos' legal team argues that the auction violated US bankruptcy law, and the company and its major shareholders are determined to pursue legal action against any entity that acquires its assets.

Voters are flocking to the blog awards site, where voting is currently underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best weblogs—online platforms where individuals share their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but the high volume of traffic to the official site caused it to temporarily shut down. Thirty categories are represented, including Best Regional Blog and Best Kept Secret Blog. Blogs have experienced significant growth, with Merriam-Webster Dictionary naming "blog" the Word of the Year 2004. According to Technorati, a blog search engine, over 6 million blogs are tracked, and approximately 12,000 new ones are added daily. Pew Internet and American Life Project reports that while a new blog is created every 5.8 seconds, fewer than 40% are updated at least twice a month.

The China Three Gorges Project Corporation is defying a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams, according to the Chinese state media. Despite the directive, the company continues to work on the Xiluodu Dam, another major project that has faced criticism for lacking proper environmental evaluations. Instead of halting construction, the firm may opt to pay a penalty. Additionally, it has disregarded instructions to cease work at two related projects – the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Electrical Power Supply Plant. Only 22 of the 30 projects singled out by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct adequate environmental impact studies have complied with the shutdown order so far.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points after securing a hard-fought victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney connected with Gary Neville's cross at the near post, firing a low shot that took a fortuitous deflection off Richard Dunne before finding its way into the net. Seven minutes later, the hapless Dunne inadvertently directed a volley over David James' head and into his own goal. Steve McManaman squandered City's best opportunity in the first half, shooting wide from close range. Prior to this, United had struggled to create clear-cut chances, with their build-up play being more laborious than purposeful. They did manage to carve out one decent opportunity, however, which resulted in a Paul Scholes header sailing over the crossbar.

Wales must learn health lessons, the new health minister for Wales says. There are lessons to be learned from England in tackling waiting lists, according to Dr. Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the job after Jane Hutt was dismissed. Admitting "significant challenges," Dr. Gibbons maintained that the "fundamentals" were in place. However, Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats argued that Dr. Gibbons needs to adjust his policies. In defense of her record, Ms. Hutt stated that waiting times and lists constituted only 10% of the health agenda. As a former GP in Blaengwynfi, in the Upper Afan Valley, and now AM for Aberavon, Dr. Gibbons acknowledged that NHS staff desire a period of stability following "substantial change and reform." One of the primary issues Ms. Hutt faced during her five-and-a-half years as the Assembly's first health minister was the prolonged waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson lauds Manchester United's resilience after 1-0 victory at Aston Villa.
"That was our toughest away match of the season, and it was an excellent display of football, with both teams creating plenty of scoring opportunities," said the Old Trafford manager. "We demonstrated great spirit and determination, refusing to accept defeat. I consider this fixture a success, whereas Arsenal and Chelsea still have to face them, and Villa might have some key players back by then." Ferguson also commended veteran players Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who replaced the injured John O'Shea. "Roy provided a calming presence in midfield, which we needed and only he could deliver.

Singer's film to show at festival: A documentary featuring George Michael, which offers a frank look at his life, will be displayed at this year's Berlin Film Festival. Another tale will be presented in the Panorama section of the festival, running from February 10th to 20th. The documentary showcases the artist discussing his professional and private experiences, from his time in Wham! to current events. Michael will attend the festival on February 16th to present the screening. Joining him will be Director Southan Morris and Executive Producer Andy Stephens. Lasting 93 minutes, the film explores Michael's early years in Wham!, as well as his solo career, including his legal disputes with Sony Records and his opposition to the Iraq War and American politics.

"Downloads now enter the US singles chart as digital music downloads are included in the main chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart has integrated data from music download sales, previously featured in a separate download chart. Green Day's 'Boulevard of Broken Dreams' holds the number two spot in Billboard's Pop Chart and leads its Digital Chart. Download sales will be incorporated into the UK Singles Chart later this year. In the US, digital sales are already utilized to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales Chart. They will now be combined with physical single sales and airplay data to create the revamped Hot 100 Chart. A second new chart, the Pop 100, merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but limits its airplay data to US radio stations playing chart music."

Anti-spam laws have dealt a severe blow to a prominent spammer, as the self-proclaimed "spam king" of the internet has sought bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, founder of optinrealbig.com and responsible for an astronomical number of junk emails, claims that mounting legal challenges necessitated this drastic measure. Optinrealbig faces multiple court battles, including a high-profile case against Microsoft, which seeks substantial damages. In hopes of resolving these issues while maintaining operations, the company has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Previously, Spamhaus, a leading anti-spam organization, listed optinrealbig as the world's third-largest spammer. A December 2003 lawsuit initiated by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer accused Mr. Richter and his associates of dispatching billions of unsolicited emails through 514 hijacked internet domains across 35 nations, thereby violating strict anti-spam regulations.

Arnesen dismisses rift with Santini Tottenham Hotspur sporting director Frank Arnesen has refuted claims that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a personality conflict at White Hart Lane. Newspaper reports suggested that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "Absolutely untrue," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "The only reason he resigned is due to personal issues. He has confided in me recently, stating that this matter is entirely personal. I am unable to provide insight into the specific problems that led Santini to step down after merely 13 games in charge. However, I do believe we must respect his privacy regarding this issue."

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam aspirations with an emphatic victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 advantage, but Ireland quickly regained control with tries from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell before halftime. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and three penalties from Ronan O'Gara, who tallied 13 points, further extended Ireland's lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy secured the win for Ireland. Following two tough away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's team can now prepare for England's visit to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Meanwhile, Scotland will aim to give coach Matt Williams his first Six Nations triumph when Italy arrive in Edinburgh, though they continued to struggle in converting pressure into points.

Economic policy will take center stage in Britain's upcoming election, according to Chancellor Gordon Brown. Speaking after the final Cabinet meeting at No. 10 before the anticipated election announcement, Brown asserted that voters would recognize Labour's achievements in bringing stability and growth to the economy and trust the party to continue doing so. Meanwhile, the Conservatives unveiled their plan to address "yob culture," while the Liberal Democrats provided additional details about their proposal to replace council tax. In a related development, the Archbishop of Canterbury penned an open letter to all three parties, urging them not to resort to fear-mongering tactics during the election campaign. Specifically, he cautioned against using terrorism, asylum, and crime as tools to scare voters into supporting one party over another.

Brizzel to run AAAs in Sheffield; Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European Indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA Championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British Trials. In-form James McIlroy will hope to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in exceptional form on the European circuit in recent weeks, boasting one of the fastest 800m times in the world this winter and seemingly assuring him a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed in midweek that he would join Cragg in the European Championships, with Carroll currently ranked third in the world 3000m rankings, behind Cragg who holds the top spot.

Robinson seeks dual-code triumph for England Rugby Union captain Jason Robinson has set his sights on achieving success in both rugby codes when England faces Australia on Saturday. A former rugby league international who switched to union in 2000, Robinson will lead England against Australia at Twickenham at 14:30 GMT, followed by Great Britain's rugby league team taking on Australia in the Tri-Nations Tournament final at 18:15 GMT. "Beating the Australians in both games would be an immense accomplishment, particularly for league," Robinson noted. England has the opportunity to secure its third consecutive autumn international victory, building on previous wins over Canada and South Africa, while also exacting revenge for June's 51-15 defeat to the Wallabies. Moreover, Great Britain could break a 34-year losing streak against Australia with a victory at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid: Net users are being cautioned to steer clear of a fraudulent website that purports to collect donations on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate as it employs an outdated version of the authentic Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, DEC has no affiliation with the bogus site and has alerted law enforcement authorities. This latest scam joins a lengthy list of others attempting to capitalize on the generosity sparked by the tsunami tragedy. An email containing the website link is currently making the rounds, sporting a subject line reading "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal." The message's content exhibits the characteristic poor grammar and misspellings found in numerous phishing attempts.

Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to substantially enhance nationwide coverage over the next decade. The Ministry of Communications has invited local, Arab, and foreign companies to participate in the bidding process. The successful bidder will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to establish and operate a fixed-line phone network, offering voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry hopes to raise Iraq's current "very low" telephone service penetration rate of 4.5% to 25% within ten years and create a "visible and dynamic telecommunications sector." Information regarding the bidding and tender process will be available on the ministry's website starting February 9, with a roadshow for investors taking place in Amman, Jordan.

More women are turning to internet security, particularly older individuals, who are increasingly taking responsibility for safeguarding their home computers against malevolent online threats, according to a two-year investigation. The annual growth rate for females purchasing software to shield personal computers from viruses, spam, and spyware assaults was 11.2% between 2002 and 2004. The survey conducted by Preventon, a cybersecurity company, indicates that safety warnings are resonating with various internet users. Approximately 40% of consumers investing in residential internet protection systems are retirees, which has increased at an average pace of 13.2% over the past three years. Notably, retired women (53%) constitute a majority among retired individuals acquiring such software, outnumbering retired males. This trend reflects both the shifting image and population dynamics of web users and the mounting recognition of the heightened vulnerability associated with high-speed broadband connectivity.

Podcasts signal the ascension of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music player can store up to 10,000 songs, providing ample space for creative expression. However, increasing numbers of iPod owners are utilizing this capacity to accommodate audio content generated by a diverse array of producers. This phenomenon is known as "podcasting," championed by former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry. Although the term derives from the Apple iPod, one does not require an iPod to produce or enjoy a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio program that podcasters create from the comfort of their homes, using just a microphone, PC, and editing software. After recording and producing their shows, they upload them to the web for others to download and listen to freely.

Levy wins Whitbread Novel Prize; Orange Prize winner Andrea Levy has won the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award with her book Small Island. She is now the front-runner to capture the top honor after defeating Booker laureate Alan Hollinghurst's The Line of Beauty. Geraldine McCaughrean has claimed the Children's Fiction Award for the third time with Not the End of the World. The winners of each category advance to contend for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which comes with a £25,000 prize. A distinguished panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and author Joanne Harris, will convene on January 25th to select the overall victor, with the announcement slated for that evening. According to bookmaker William Hill, London-based Levy's novel is the 6/4 favorite to triumph.

Yukos is seeking legal recourse through the courts regarding the sale of its main asset. On Wednesday, the company will return to a US court to request sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the relatively unknown firm that purchased Yukos' primary asset. Yukos has stated its intention to pursue legal action against Baikal and other parties involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas, seeking $20 billion in damages. Following the Russian government's disregard for a US court order that blocked the sale, Yukos' American attorneys will endeavor to have Baikal's assets frozen. Speculation about Baikal's motivations for acquiring the unit and its connections to Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer, remain unclear.

Heart of Midlothian (Hearts) defeated Livingston 2-1 in their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie, courtesy of two early goals. Lee Miller opened the scoring within the first minute, directing Jamie McAllister's free kick beyond Colin Meldrum and into the net. McAllister then added the second, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to secure the win. Although Craig Easton netted a contentious goal for Livingston after an hour, Hearts managed to hold on for victory. The initial goal resulted from Gus Bahoken's careless foul on Miller 35 yards from the target. McAllister's ensuing free kick found its way into the Livingston box, where Miller outleaped the stationary away defense to nod home from 10 yards. Just ten minutes elapsed before Hearts struck again. Mikoliunas darted down the flank, delivering a pinpoint cross to the far post, which McAllister met with a well-timed run to guide past Meldrum.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service that enables clients needing substantial computational resources to lease them on an hourly basis. Dubbed "grid computing," this concept is Sun's latest brainchild, likened to the evolution of electricity. According to Chief Operating Officer Jonathan Schwartz, grid computing is poised to follow a similar growth trajectory as utility services like electricity and water. At just $1 (53p) per hour, Sun Grid provides users with both processing and storage capabilities, all managed by Sun. When queried about the benefits of using Sun's grid versus building one's own, Schwartz posed a rhetorical question during his webcast speech at Sun's Network Computing Event in California: "Why invest in your own infrastructure when you can tap into ours for a mere dollar per hour?"

Jamieson cautions bigots; Scotland's Justice Minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she intends to penalize them "where it hurts most" by barring them from games. Cathy Jamieson stated that exclusion orders are among several measures being explored as part of the Scottish Executive's drive against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing the issue. Nevertheless, the Minister emphasized that eradicating sectarian abuse connected with Old Firm matches remains a top priority. Ms. Jamieson made these remarks before the third-round Scottish Cup encounter between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The longstanding sectarianism prevailing among certain supporters of both teams has become a prime target for the Executive. In a recent meeting, Ms. Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell consulted with representatives from both clubs' fan bases to discuss potential solutions.

Uk debut for Kevin Spacey movie Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of their new film, Beyond the Sea, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, which was inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I believe was an extraordinary talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, performs all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, portrays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I was previously unfamiliar with Bobby Darin's work, but now I'm a big fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere alongside her British boyfriend Orlando Bloom.

Leeds vs Saracens (Fri) Headingley Friday, February 25, 2000 GMT The Yorkshire Carnegie team, known as "the Tykes," has brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Scottish Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez will start at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes to their lineup. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also included in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell takes his place at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley received the green light after a successful pitch inspection earlier in the day. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham.
Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an uncertain future as the traditional landline phone in your home could soon become a rarity. A recent study conducted by Nokia, a leading handset manufacturer, indicates that an increasing number of individuals are relying exclusively on their mobile phones for all their calling needs. The survey, which covered the UK, Germany, US, and South Korea, found that over 45 million people have abandoned their landlines altogether. While respondents cited lower call charges as the primary reason for keeping their fixed lines, the majority believed that the future belongs to mobile technology. The Nokia-sponsored research also revealed that mobiles and fixed phones serve distinct purposes, with home phones being used for lengthier conversations and mobiles primarily used for shorter talks, often between friends and within the same network. Notably, 69% of British respondents admitted to preferring their fixed phones due to their comparatively lower costs.

Melzer stuns Agassi; second seed falls in San Jose Andre Agassi suffered a decisive defeat at the hands of Jurgen Melzer in the quarterfinals of the SAP Open. The Austrian's clever use of drop shots left Agassi bewildered, resulting in a 6-3, 6-1 loss. Top seed and defending champion Andy Roddick battled back to overcome Sweden's Thomas Enqvist in a thrilling match, winning 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Meanwhile, unseeded Cyril Saulnier upset fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, and Tommy Haas edged out eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. With this victory, Melzer has now defeated Agassi in two of their three encounters. "I had a solid game plan and executed it flawlessly," Melzer said in a post-match interview. "It's always challenging to face Andre. I aimed to prevent him from dictating the pace of the match. He can make you run circles around the court."

A group of MPs has sought to increase pressure on Tony Blair regarding House of Lords reform by publicizing a comprehensive plan for change. The cross-party group has introduced a draft bill that proposes a smaller secondary chamber with 70% of its members being elected. Attempts at reform by MPs and peers have been unsuccessful since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their positions. The group believes it can garner support for eliminating the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government previously delayed plans to remove these peers due to concerns about facing opposition from the Lords. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for a consensus on reforms, and there have been rumors that Labour's manifesto may include proposals for modifying the Lords' powers.

Disappointed Scott eyes strong finish at European Indoors Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships, despite a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning experience, and I haven't given up on my chances of challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who matched the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg took second place, while Haiti's Dudley Dorival finished third. Although slightly disappointed with his performance in the final, Scott had won his heat in 7.64 seconds, just 0.04 seconds off his personal best time.

A Georgia woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP) alleging that the company's printer ink cartridges are designed to expire on a specific date, regardless of their actual ink level. The plaintiff, who wishes to remain anonymous, asserts that a chip embedded in the cartridge misleads the printer into thinking it needs refilling, even when there is still ink remaining. The lawsuit aims to represent all US individuals who have purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the global leader in printer sales, declined to comment on the legal action. The company's ink cartridges utilize chip technology to detect when they are running low on ink and alert the user to replace them. However, the lawsuit contends that these chips also trigger the cartridges to cease functioning on a predefined date, irrespective of their actual capacity.

Virgin Radio is set to revolutionize mobile entertainment by offering 3G broadcasts in the UK. In collaboration with technology partner Sydus, the radio station will transmit its signal on select 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Listeners can expect to download software from the Virgin Radio website later this year, enabling them to access the service on their mobile devices. James Cridland, Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, expressed his excitement about the development, stating, "This innovation puts radio at the forefront of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station to be made available through the application, followed by two additional digital stations, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. According to Mr. Cridland, "Our application will empower anyone, anywhere to enjoy Virgin Radio with just their phone in hand."

Roxy Music is set to perform at June's Isle of Wight Festival, joined by Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, taking place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take the stage on Saturday evening. The band is currently working in the studio on new material, their first release since Avalon in 1982. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their initial success came with "Virginia Plain" in 1972, followed by hits like "Street Life," "Love is the Drug," and their 1981 cover of John Lennon's "Jealous Guy."

"Captains lining up for aid match; Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is among four Six Nations captains selected for the IRB Rugby Aid Match on March 5th. Joining him in the Northern Hemisphere squad are France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bulloch, and Italy's Marco Bortolami. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod MacQueen's Southern Hemisphere side in a tsunami fundraising match at Twickenham. 'I'm excited to work with such exceptional players,' Woodward said. This game presents an opportunity for him to evaluate some of his options before announcing the British and Irish Lions touring party, who will travel to New Zealand this summer. 'The match promises to be an excellent display,' he added."

Spirit awards lavish praise on Sideways, which has dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, securing all six awards for which it was nominated. The film earned Best Picture honors, while Alexander Payne received Best Director and Best Screenplay accolades, collaborating with Jim Taylor on the latter. Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen respectively garnered Acting awards for their roles in the movie. With five Academy Award nominations, Sideways is poised for success at Sunday's ceremony. Now in its 20th year, the Independent Spirit Awards recognize exceptional films produced outside the conventional studio framework and take place one day prior to the Oscars. Additional victors included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who secured Best Actress for her portrayal of a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama Maria Full of Grace; she has also been Oscar-nominated for this performance. Joshua Marston claimed the Best First Screenplay prize for his work on Maria Full of Grace.

Prince was named the top music earner by Rolling Stone magazine, outranking fellow pop stars Madonna and Elton John. In 2004, the artist brought in $56.5 million (£30.4 million) from concerts, albums, and publishing sales, thanks to his successful Musicology Tour and album release. Madonna followed closely behind, earning $54.9 million (£29.5 million) through her Global Re-Invention Tour. Simon & Garfunkel, who made a comeback that year, came in at number ten on the list, earning $24.9 million (£13.4 million) from their tour. According to Rolling Stone, Prince's return to center stage was particularly notable given his absence from the spotlight for over a decade. His 2004 tour generated an impressive $90.3 million (£48.5 million) in ticket sales alone, and his latest album, Musicology, sold 1.9 million copies worldwide.

Blue defeated U2 to claim the top honor at France's most prestigious music awards. Although U2 received a special achievement prize at the NRJ Music Awards, Blue won the International Group Award. Maroon 5, a US band, was named Best New International Artist and also secured the Best International Song title for their hit "This Love." Over five million radio listeners cast their votes in the awards. Usher and Avril Lavigne respectively won the International Male and Female Prizes. Accepting his band's award from supermodel Naomi Campbell at the Cannes ceremony, Bono, U2's lead singer, declared in French, "Although I am not from this country, I must confess that it's here at the Côte d'Azur where I truly feel at home."

Wal-Mart is fighting back against its critics with a series of advertisements aimed at setting the record straight about its products and corporate practices. The world's largest retailer has taken out over 100 full-page ads in national newspapers to counter criticisms regarding its compensation packages, employee benefits, and career advancement opportunities. Separately, drug manufacturer Eli Lilly is preparing a campaign to refute false claims about its product Prozac. In kicking off the effort, Wal-Mart President Lee Scott penned an open letter featured in publications such as The Wall Street Journal, emphasizing the need for the public to hear the unvarnished truth. "There are plenty of misconceptions circulating about Wal-Mart, but facts are facts."

Tories have outlined plans for local communities to elect their own area police commissioners, as part of efforts to enhance community-based policing. Under the proposed scheme, the new role would replace existing "obscure" police authorities, according to Conservative Party leader Michael Howard. However, he emphasized that the new position would not supersede the responsibilities of a chief constable. The Liberal Democrats have expressed concerns that the plan might allow extremist groups to exert control over policing, while Labour has criticized the "lavish" Tory promises on law enforcement. In response to the proposal, Jan Berry, Chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents frontline officers, stressed the importance of preserving operational independence. She cautioned, "Policing is a vital public service, not a political tool to be exploited during elections. These plans may lead to individuals with radical ideologies dictating policing strategies, which could compromise public safety."

At a glance: The UK's Conservative Party has proposed introducing health checks for immigrants if they win the upcoming general election. Here's a summary of their plan: People arriving in Britain from non-EU countries who intend to reside and work for six months or longer, and hail from nations with high incidences of tuberculosis (TB), will be required to undergo a chest X-ray and additional testing as necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union seeking to remain in the UK for a year or more will need to undergo a comprehensive medical examination covering TB, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB diagnosis would result in automatic denial of visa applications. Other conditions would be evaluated on a case-by-case basis.

Paris performance raises Welsh hopes: Has there been a more thrilling Six Nations match than Saturday's encounter in Paris? And can the Welsh resurgence continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? These are the questions captivating not only Wales supporters but also the entire rugby community after an exhilarating display in France. Welsh icon Mervyn Davies, a member of two of the three Grand Slam-winning teams of the 1970s, praised it as "one of the greatest displays in recent history." Martyn Williams, who scored twice for Wales, described it as "one of the most extraordinary matches I've ever played in." A defeated France coach, Bernard Laporte, could only remark, "There were two halves: a French one and a Welsh one."

Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart with their new release, "Some Cities," replacing flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the summit. The album follows the successful single "Black and White Town," which peaked at number six. R&B star Nelly has claimed the new number one single with "Over and Over," featuring Tim McGraw. Additionally, Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, along with Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, "(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame," entered the chart at number three, just ahead of Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up." Akon's "Locked Up" sits at number five, while Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have scored their second chart hit with "Oh My God" at number six.

Davies prefers a future with Gloucester, despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. According to BBC Wales, the Ospreys are keen on the 32-year-old, but he is inclined to remain with his current club. Davies, who shone in Saturday's RBS Six Nations victory over England, is currently on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, his impressive performances have made him an asset to the Zurich Premiership side, and he is expected to secure a new deal next season. Following the summer dissolution of the Celtic Warriors region, Davies found himself out of contract and took a semi-professional role with Neath RFC. Although he gained match experience with the Ospreys through arrangements made by the Wales management, he confessed before joining Gloucester that he felt aggrieved about how his situation unfolded.

Cabinet discontent with the redirection of funds to cap council tax increases has been acknowledged by Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford. Chancellor Gordon Brown recently allocated £512 million from central government coffers to local councils as part of a £1 billion package aimed at limiting council tax hikes in England during a potential election year. Raynsford confirmed having candid conversations with cabinet colleagues regarding the plan, emphasizing the need for efficient municipal services without excessive tax burdens. He noted that most Whitehall departments have a vested interest in effectively managed local authorities.

Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin is set to feature four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, in their UEFA Cup campaign. Bnei Sakhnin, the first Arab side to participate in European competition, will face English Premier League team Newcastle United in the opening round. Murambadoro, who gained recognition during the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin defeat Albanian club Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. After a brief stint with South African club Hellenic, Murambadoro joined Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin, which is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. The club has a strong commitment to promoting peace and cooperation within Israel and boasts a high profile in this regard.

A new study suggests that lowering the legal drink-driving limit could save more lives than initially thought. According to research conducted by Professor Richard Allsop at University College London, reducing the limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood would annually save 65 lives and prevent 230 severe injuries on UK roads. This proposal is supported by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, who are urging MPs to consider the change as they prepare to vote on the Government's Road Safety Bill. While the bill addresses speeding penalties, it does not address the drink-drive limit. The research estimates that implementing this change would not only save lives but also provide an economic benefit of £119 million per year. Notably, a 1998 Department of Transport report had previously estimated that a similar reduction in the limit could save 50 lives annually.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64x64 single-charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a substantial detection area of 512x512 μm². Unlike traditional systems, the proposed design does not rely on sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation; instead, it measures the pulse width, specifically the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This approach eliminates the need for bulky and power-intensive analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC fabricated in TSMC 65nm LP CMOS technology consumers an average static power of 0.535mW under 1.2V analog and digital power supplies. The entire system's functionality was successfully validated in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam environment.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, assuming AVs will readily submit to external control by a central agency is unrealistic. This paper proposes a joint routing and pricing control scheme that incentivizes AVs to adopt centrally controlled system-optimal (SO) routing by offering toll savings, while maintaining user equilibrium (UE) for both AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) under a congestion charging framework. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, and the lower level employs a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model, considering a diverse fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature-squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This breakthrough has not only led to the manipulation of increasingly large and tangible objects in the quantum realm but also sparked ideas for utilizing mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing and precision force sensing beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the inherently linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to a wider range of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy-squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals recognized the potential to overcome this limitation by introducing strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. While experiments have demonstrated quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, they have yet to achieve nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews provide product assessments for consumers to base their purchasing decisions on. However, these evaluations can be tampered with through the use of fake reviews (also known as "spams") created by skilled spammers who have developed sophisticated and effective spamming techniques by adapting to the various detectors that have been implemented. These tactics are difficult to pin down because they can change rapidly over time, differ between spammers and target products, and often remain undetected. Most current detectors prioritize detection precision, which doesn't necessarily align with the primary objective of preserving the reliability of product reviews. In response, we devise a minimax game where spammers and spam detectors engage in a competition centered around their functional objectives, rather than purely focusing on detection accuracy. The Nash equilibria of this game yield stable detectors that are immune to any combination of detection methods employed by spammers.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high-fidelity population transfer on a three-level quantum system in a lambda configuration. To ensure optimal fidelity, we utilize the Lewis-Riesenfeld method to generate a set of solutions that lead to precise population transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the Lewis-Riesenfeld invariant. From this set, we identified a tracking solution with a single parameter that controls the fidelity, excited-state population, and robustness simultaneously. Our definition of robustness for ultra-high-fidelity transfers is the minimum percentage deviation in pulse areas required for the infidelity to exceed $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses outperforms Gaussian and adiabatic pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we investigate the topography of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with an arbitrary number of components. Because of nonconvexity, multiple local minima may arise, even when the mixture is well separated. We demonstrate that all local minima possess a similar structural form that partially pinpoints the component centers of the genuine mixture, in the sense that each local minimum entails a non-overlapping combination of adapting several Gaussians to a single authentic component and adapting a single Gaussian to numerous authentic components. Our findings hold for the scenario where the actual mixture components fulfill a specific separation criterion and remain valid regardless of whether the number of components is correctly or incorrectly specified. When dealing with Gaussian mixtures having three components, our outcomes become more precise as the separation between the components increases. The modifications made were primarily focused on enhancing the precision and clarity of the language used while preserving the original sentence structure. Some of the key adjustments included: 1. Replaced "study" with "investigate" to convey a more appropriate sense of examination and exploration.
2.

We explore the relationship between two constructions of the mirror partner for a Calabi-Yau orbifold. The orbifold is defined as a quotient of the phase symmetries of a hypersurface $x_m$ in a weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$, by a suitable subgroup $G$. The first construction, due to Berglund, Hübsch, and Krawitz (BHK), employs another weighted projective space and takes the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ within it by some dual group $G^t$. In contrast, the second construction, developed by Batyrev, builds the mirror partner as a hypersurface within the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a straightforward argument demonstrating the equivalence of these two approaches.

In this study, we generalized existing models of human gait from the literature, such as Keller and Kocksheniev's models, to develop a novel approach. Our hybrid model combines a metabolic energy minimization strategy with a nonlinear description of the mass center's oscillatory motion, aiming to replicate the walk-run transition. Experimental data obtained at various speed regimes suggest that the perimeter of the mass center's trajectory plays a significant role in characterizing this dynamics. We collaborated with the Biomedical Engineering Research Group, Basic Sciences, and Laboratories at Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia to conduct the experiments.

We introduce a novel mixed-variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that accurately resolves close encounters. Our method is built upon a time regularization technique that preserves the stability attributes of symplectic integrators while adaptively decreasing the effective step size during planetary interactions. By employing a high-order MVS scheme, we can integrate with large time steps in regions where close encounters are not occurring. This algorithm enables the precise resolution of nearly exact collisions (with a mutual separation of a small fraction of the physical radius) using the same time step as in weakly perturbed problems, such as the solar system. In a series of simulations spanning 50,000 years, we demonstrate the long-term behavior of our algorithm on systems consisting of six super-Earths undergoing intense scattering. Our approach shows superior energy conservation compared to hybrid methods like Mercury, while maintaining comparable computational efficiency.

Entanglement is a vital resource for quantum information processing. A commonly used method for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, which guarantees a positive measurement outcome for all separable states and can exhibit negativity for certain entangled states. However, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for generic multipartite entangled states is a formidable task due to the exponential growth of the Hilbert space dimension with respect to the number of parties involved. For Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) like states with $n$ parties, the most resilient witness scheme necessitates $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to half a unit of white noise. In contrast, the optimal witness for GHZ-like states requires only two local measurements and can withstand up to one-third of white noise.

Within general relativity, the singular stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which has a distinctive multipolar structure dependent solely on its mass and spin. We have developed a universal method to extract the multipole moments of any stationary spacetime and applied it to a broad family of horizonless microstate geometries. These microstates can violate the axial and equatorial symmetries of the Kerr metric, resulting in a wealthier multipolar structure that offers a means to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. Our numerical results indicate that the multipole moments of such microstates are generally larger in absolute value than those of a Kerr black hole with the identical mass and spin. Present observations of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates can impose only modest limitations on fuzzballs, but upcoming gravitational-wave detectors like LISA will enhance these constraints by several orders of magnitude through the detection of extreme mass-ratio inspirals.

Reasoning about graph evolution over time poses significant challenges across various domains, including bioinformatics, physics, and social networking. We address a common scenario where edge relationships can be either brief interactions, such as messaging, or long-term structural connections, like friendships. While long-term edges are typically designated by humans, they can be costly to establish and may not optimize downstream tasks. Our proposed model leverages temporal point processes and variational autoencoders to infer temporal attention between nodes by analyzing node communication patterns. By learning this essential component from observed node interactions, our approach offers greater adaptability while sidestepping the limitations of human-defined edges.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibrations of a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW) are presented. The PCW comprises two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. Researchers have developed and validated models for the conversion of beam motion into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe transmitted through the guided mode (GM) of the PCW, both at frequencies distant from and close to the dielectric band edge. As the PCW was specifically designed for near-field atom trapping, these findings lay the groundwork for assessing potential detrimental impacts of thermal motion on optical atomic traps positioned near the surface of PCWs. Ultimately, scientists aim to establish robust atom-mediated connections between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating within the GMs of the PCW, paving the way for quantum-level optomechanics involving atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Specifically, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in these splittings stems from equivariant stable homotopy theory, where the equivariant stable homotopy groups of each global spectrum form a global Mackey functor. Consequently, the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences decompose into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{MO}$ and $\mathbf{MU}$, the splittings have implications for the regularity of various Euler classes associated with the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$.

Baryonic feedback mechanisms result in a repression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum at diminutive scales. The poorly defined contours and magnitude of this repression pose a significant source of ambiguities for impending cosmological weak lensing surveys, such as Euclid or LSST. In the initial publication of our two-part series, we utilize simulations to create a Euclid-like tomographic mock dataset encompassing the cosmic shear power spectrum and its associated covariance matrix, both of which have been adjusted for baryonic impacts employing Schneider et al.'s (2019) baryonification technique. Additionally, we devise an emulator to expedite predictions of the baryonic power restraint, thereby enabling a likelihood inference investigation for a conventional λCDM cosmology, encompassing both cosmological and astrophysical variables.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those captured in child-centered recordings, pose significant challenges for speech processing. Nonetheless, developing models capable of handling such variability would be highly valuable for language acquisition studies, which aim to quantify and assess the quality of speech that children are exposed to and produce, as well as for early detection and measurement of intervention efficacy. In this paper, we present our methodology for creating an open-source neural network that categorizes audio segments into vocalizations made by the recorded child, vocalizations made by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To achieve this, we compiled a diverse collection of child-focused corpora, totaling 260 hours of recordings and representing 10 languages.

Density-based clustering hinges on the notion of connecting clusters to distinct aspects of the underlying probability distribution of the data. By assuming a genuine, though unobserved, population structure, we can frame the clustering problem within a conventional inferential framework, where the concept of optimal clusterization is defined as the partition generated by the true density function. This approach's nonparametric formulation, referred to as modal clustering, establishes a relationship between the clusters and the attractors of the density function's local maxima. To operationalize this method, a suitable nonparametric density estimate is necessary, and selecting the appropriate amount of smoothing—which influences the density's shape and potentially the resulting cluster configuration—is critical to obtain the ultimate partition. Our work tackles the challenge of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic standpoint.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interplay between the Standard Model and higher-dimensional operators that describe the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes pose an obstacle to the straightforward interference contributions of dimension-six operators, resulting in the cancellation of the leading correction to the total diboson rate. By carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles, the interference is restored, regaining sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We investigate these signatures thoroughly and find that the EFT uncertainties related to higher-dimensional operators are remarkably well-suppressed by constructing an asymmetry variable that is generated exclusively by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the level of statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is the aim of numerous data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academia has historically disapproved of data analyses with a causal objective. The emergence of the term "data science" presents a unique opportunity to redefine data analysis in a manner that seamlessly encompasses causal inference from observational data. Similar to previous efforts, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three categories of tasks: descriptive analysis, predictive modeling, and counterfactual reasoning (inclusive of causal inference). A clear delineation of data science tasks is essential to address the diverse data requirements, underlying presumptions, and appropriate methodologies involved in each endeavor. We posit that a lack of emphasis on the integral role of domain-specific knowledge in data analysis is a primary source of pervasive misconceptions regarding data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) necessitates the presence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The conventional wisdom is that these particles are introduced to guarantee instability or marginal stability of extremal black holes, but it remains unclear what goes awry if this fails to occur. This note demonstrates that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in anti-de Sitter (AdS) space, the exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with rigorously established quantum information theorems regarding entanglement entropy. To reconcile this tension, we derive a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the familiar statement at weak coupling. Our argument applies generally, relying solely on the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography, without assuming supersymmetry or a specific ultraviolet (UV) completion.

Understanding how two-dimensional (2D) systems can exhibit unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures remains a significant challenge in condensed matter physics. Ultralow-temperature 2D Fermi gases have emerged as pristine and controllable models to investigate the interplay between robust correlations and diminished dimensionality. However, direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. In this work, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultralow-temperature 2D Fermi gas by applying a periodic potential and observing negligible dissipation beneath a critical velocity, v$_c$. We determine v$_c$'s dependence on interaction intensity and discover a maximum in the crossover region between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our finding confirms ultralow-temperature fermion systems as a valuable tool for examining how decreased dimensionality affects intensely correlated superfluids.

"Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) are widely employed in various fields, including climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, due to their intuitive ability to model complex phenomena. However, the lack of analytical solutions for ODEs often hinders the estimation of model parameters from data, particularly when dealing with models that involve numerous variables and parameters. To address this challenge, we propose a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that exhibits both efficiency and accuracy, even when applied to models with a large number of parameters. Our approach involves approximating an ODE model using a state-space model derived from the equations of a numerical solver. By doing so, we can circumvent the computationally expensive task of generating a complete numerical solution within the likelihood function. Instead, we resort to a variational Bayes method, specifically the Approximate Riemannian Conjugate Gradient Method (Honkela et al.), to obtain the posterior distribution."

We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in NSN junctions fabricated from a Weyl semimetal (WSM) in close proximity to an $s$-wave superconductor. Our studies reveal that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes exhibit a strong dependence on the angular orientation between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We uncover the impact of a chiral chemical potential, namely, the electronic population disparity between Weyl nodes of opposing chirality, on the transport behavior of the junction. Notably, we detect a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated through Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. The spin polarization displays an opposite sign in the two WSM regions and demonstrates pronounced sensitivity to both the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has proven to be a reliable and controlled technique for modifying the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic pieces, and has been utilized in various applications. Notably, it enables the gradient of voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, thus increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied without surface discharge. However, a concern associated with this method is the long-term durability of the conductivity induced by implantation, particularly when the implanted metal species is prone to oxidation. In this study, we investigated the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of alumina implanted with titanium. Our findings reveal that while there was an initial decline of up to 40% in the first few weeks post-implantation, the conductivity exhibited a negligible decrease of approximately 10% over the ensuing year.

We present a novel conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, inspired by the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is analogous to the Skyrme charge for any smooth configuration. Moreover, we identify singular configurations that can be regarded as N_f = 1 baryons charged under the newly proposed symmetry. These vector mesons play the role of Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that constitutes the N_f = 1 baryon. We suggest that this current provides the appropriate effective representation of the baryon current at low energies. Our proposal offers a coherent framework for understanding both types of baryons and enables a seamless transformation between them. Furthermore, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a consequence of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions provides an intriguing approach to combining anomalous Hall and Josephson phenomena in a single device. We investigate theoretically how the superposition of these two effects affects the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. By considering transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface, we observe sizable transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. Building upon the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially developed to quantify conventional Josephson current flows, we generalized it to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes can be widely tuned via the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. Notably, well-localized subgap bound states emerge around the interface, serving as a distinctive spectroscopic signature of Josephson junctions.

Following Jiménez et al.'s (2020) Monte Carlo experiments, which demonstrated that dipoles play a role comparable to individual vortex cores in the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence, we find that the kinetic energy of this flow is primarily carried by elongated streams composed of concatenated dipoles. The vortices segregate into two distinct populations: smaller, rapidly moving cores and larger, slower-moving structures that can be characterized as a 'frozen' crystal. The kinematics of these populations differ significantly, with only the former exhibiting self-similar behavior. The latter accounts for most of the flow's kinetic energy and forms the dipoles and streams. We discuss mechanisms contributing to the growth of this slow component.

Continuous-time quantum walks have emerged as a valuable framework for developing various quantum algorithms. The performance of these algorithms is often gauged by the quantum hitting time – the duration it takes for the quantum walk to locate a specific vertex with high likelihood. This article presents enhanced upper bounds for the quantum hitting time, applicable to multiple quantum algorithms based on continuous-time quantum walks. Notably, our techniques significantly enhance the hitting time upper bound for the glued-trees problem, reducing it from $O(n^5)$ to $O(n^2 \log n)$. Additionally, our methods substantially improve the dependence on precision of Chakraborty et al.'s continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm for finding a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain, leading to exponential improvement.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be categorized as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (also known as "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered the primary source for the laser interferometer space antenna, are mainly produced through multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. This letter highlights an alternate EMRI formation channel: wet EMRI formation facilitated by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this scenario, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially moving on inclined orbits and subsequently propels them toward the MBH, significantly enhancing the EMRI formation rate in these galaxies by several orders of magnitude.

When a new user registers on a website, we typically have no information about them, that is, no interactions with items, no user profile, and no social connections with other users. Despite this lack of information, we still aim to captivate the users from their very first visit, encouraging them to remain engaged with the platform and eventually become active users. This challenge belongs to the new user cold-start dilemma, which is vital to the growth and success of any business. Previous studies on user cold-start recommendations often necessitate additional effort from users, such as participating in an interview process, or rely on supplementary data like user demographics, geographical locations, social networks, and so forth. Nonetheless, users might be reluctant to provide extra information, and for cold-start users, such supplementary data is frequently unavailable.

Deep learning has effectively addressed numerous challenges beyond the capabilities of traditional heuristic methods. Its applications in wireless communication have proven successful, despite the fact that existing radio systems are generally well-understood and optimized algorithms exist for various tasks. Although some progress has been made through learning individual components of a receiver separately, a more effective strategy involves simultaneously learning the entire receiver system. However, this often leads to a complex nonlinear problem where implementing an ideal solution becomes impracticable. In response, we suggest utilizing a deep fully convolutional neural network (deeprx) capable of executing the complete receiver pipeline – from frequency domain signal streams to unencoded bits in compliance with 5G standards. Our method ensures precise channel estimation by carefully designing the convolutional neural network's inputs using both data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing commonly employs an initial collection of non-crashing seed inputs (corpus) to produce new inputs through mutation. However, a large corpus may contain numerous similar inputs, leading to redundant fuzzing efforts and diminished efficiency. To overcome this limitation, fuzzers often include distillation tools (such as afl-cmin) that identify the smallest subset of seeds capable of triggering the same range of instrumentation data points as the entire corpus. By minimizing the number and total size of seeds, fuzzing becomes more efficient, a benefit we investigate systematically. Our study presents the results of 34+ cpu-years of fuzzing using five distinct distillation methods to assess their effectiveness in discovering bugs in real-world software.

In this study, we explore multi-agent discrete-event systems with incomplete information. The agents can be categorized into distinct groups, each with identical (isomorphic) state transition patterns, allowing them to be modeled using the same template. Leveraging this template, we design a scalable supervisor that exhibits negligible growth in state size and computation complexity when the number of agents increases. Notably, the supervisor remains unchanged under partial observability, eliminating the need for recalculation upon addition or removal of agents. By extending our previous findings, we establish necessary and sufficient conditions for both safety and maximum permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor within the context of partial observability. An illustrative example demonstrates the practicality of our scalable supervisory synthesis approach.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a valuable tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient method for ENF estimation utilizes temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. By exploiting the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix, we employ a Gohberg-Semencul factorization. Notably, our approach introduces the novel use of a non-rectangular temporal window prior to spectral estimation, which enhances performance. We leverage Krylov matrices for efficient matrix inversion implementations. Our proposal surpasses existing methods in ENF estimation, particularly when dealing with brief, one-second time windows in power recordings. Additionally, it produces highly precise results in speech recordings, balancing time complexity and accuracy.

The Direpack package endeavors to integrate a collection of cutting-edge statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python ecosystem as a unified, coherent library. This package encompasses three primary categories of dimension reduction methods: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, adequate dimension reduction, and robust M estimators for dimensionality reduction. Consequentially, regularized regression estimators built upon these lower-dimensional spaces are also provided, spanning from traditional principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. Additionally, Direpack includes a suite of conventional and robust preprocessing tools, such as generalized spatial sign transformations, alongside specialized visualization and cross-validation capabilities. Notably, Direpack has been designed consistent with the Scikit-Learn API, allowing seamless integration of its estimators into various (statistical and/or machine) learning workflows within that framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been extensively utilized for high-resolution optical imaging. In this study, we investigated the anomalous saturation effect of nitrogen vacancies in diamond on fluorescence. Upon exposure to high-power laser excitation, the fluorescence intensity decreased, leading to an increase in nonlinearity and a modification of the spatial frequency distribution in the resulting fluorescence image. To enhance the imaging resolution, we employed a differential excitation technique that involved modulating the laser power. This approach enabled us to achieve a near 1.6-fold improvement in spatial resolution compared to confocal microscopy. Given its straightforward experimental design and data analysis, we anticipate that our method will be useful for enhancing the resolution of sensing and biological labeling applications using solid-state defects.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the conventional approach of using individual survey weights (created to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudolikelihood no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. We develop a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that ensures unbiased inference for estimating hyperparameters of the random effects. We compare our method with frequentist techniques that rely on numerical integration and show that only the Bayesian approach attains both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generation distribution. Our simulations and real-data example for a survey of business establishments illustrate the effectiveness of our method across various modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work represents a culmination of recent advancements that integrate traditional survey estimation techniques with the Bayesian modeling framework and bridges the gap between these two rich yet distinct fields.

Low-symmetry two-dimensional materials, including Res$_2$ and ReSe$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, Group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, and other similar materials, exhibit more intricate atomic structures compared to the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The diminished symmetries of these emerging materials lead to inhomogeneous electronic, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as novel properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, substantial nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Additionally, low-symmetry two-dimensional materials can display unique electronic topological features, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transitions. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic was created to showcase recent experimental and theoretical advancements in these exciting materials.

Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was discovered that in a mesogenic polymer, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the temperature of the nematic-isotropic phase transition can be represented by a sum of several exponential processes, with two processes playing a dominant role. These primary processes alternate in a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also enabled the distinction of two orientational relaxation processes: the first arises from the rotation of the side mesogenic groups, while the second is linked to the motion of the main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated excellent retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval tasks. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a central focus in these methods. A commonly employed strategy involves utilizing an activation function, such as $\operatorname{sigmoid}$ or $\operatorname{tanh}$, and minimizing a quantization loss to approximating discrete values. However, this approach can lead to an increasing number of hash bits becoming trapped in the saturated regions of the activation functions, resulting in a phenomenon known as the "dead bits problem" (dbp). Furthermore, the existing quantization loss can exacerbate this issue. To address dbp, we introduce a straightforward yet effective gradient amplifier that operates prior to the activation functions, thereby alleviating the problem.

We investigate the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, motivated by the possibility of two-stage electroweak symmetry breaking. We explore both scenarios where the triplets are stable and contribute to dark matter density, and those where they decay through mixing with the Standard Model Higgs boson. The former is limited by vanishing charged track searches at the LHC and dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is restricted by current multi-lepton collider searches. Our analysis reveals that a two-stage electroweak phase transition featuring a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is excluded by direct detection searches, whereas an unstable triplet with a mass below $230$ GeV is ruled out at the $95\%$ confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings surrounding the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are more narrow than anticipated in the conventional eccentric planet perturbation model (occasionally referred to as "pericenter glow"). The standard scenario assumes a initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, which is later perturbed into an eccentric shape with eccentricity $e_f$ due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. However, in a slight variation of this scenario, the planetesimals may have been initially eccentric, leading to narrower belts, potentially resulting from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disk stage. Alternatively, the primordial eccentricity could stem from instabilities that elevate the disc's eccentricity, sans the presence of planets.

An electron is typically thought to possess a single type of kinetic energy, but could it harbor more, arising from its spin and charge, or by influencing neighboring electrons? In one dimension, the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model effectively captures the behavior of interacting electrons at low energies, yet experimental observations beyond this range remain scarce. Our study employs tunneling spectroscopy to investigate many-body modes in gated wires. We detect two distinct Fermi seas at elevated energies, corresponding to spin and charge excitations, as well as the emergence of three additional 1D replica modes that intensify with diminishing wire length. By varying the amount of 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%, we modify the effective interaction strength within the wires.

The assembly history of the Milky Way is currently being revealed through data from the Gaia mission. It is probable that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has undergone a similar complex formation process. Aiming to constrain this formation path, we investigate the connection between globular clusters and known merger events experienced by the Milky Way. To accomplish this, we combine kinematic information from Gaia for nearly all galactic clusters with the largest sample of cluster ages, carefully corrected for systematic errors. By examining their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion, we identify clusters with a shared origin. Our results indicate that approximately 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

The estimation of a dataset's intrinsic dimension is a vital step in many dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces Intrinsic, an R package that offers innovative, state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators for this purpose. Specifically, the package includes the two-nn, gridE, and Hidalgo models. To facilitate use of these cutting-edge estimators, Intrinsic provides several high-level, user-friendly functions that leverage a comprehensive set of efficient, low-level routines. The package covers two main types of intrinsic dimension estimators: homogeneous and heterogeneous. The former group comprises the two-nn and gridE models, for which inference can be performed within both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks using dedicated functions. Conversely, Hidalgo—a Bayesian mixture model—is covered by an effective Gibbs sampler.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrent behavior at the nanosecond scale, which holds great promise for enabling spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems, based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs), were proposed and modeled to tackle image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction tasks. Our micromagnetic simulations revealed that an RC system utilizing a single MSM demonstrates exceptional performance in recognizing handwritten digits, while a physical RC system composed of 24 STNOs can effectively solve complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems, as demonstrated in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a vital role in various online platforms, including search engines and recommendation systems. In this study, we reveal a fascinating phenomenon resulting from popularity-based rankings: the less numerous the items reporting a particular signal, the greater the combined traffic they attract. This "few-get-richer" effect materializes in environments with limited item diversity (e.g., left-leaning vs. right-leaning news sources) and popularity-based ranking. Through analytical and simulation-based experiments, we investigate how user preferences and ranking mechanisms impact the effect's intensity. Additionally, we conduct real-world tests with human participants to validate our predictions. These insights bear significant consequences for understanding the propagation of false information.

Weight pruning has gained widespread recognition as a simple yet powerful technique for eliminating redundant neurons in deep neural networks (DNNs) and thus accelerating their execution across diverse platforms. Nonetheless, many existing pruning methods involve compromising between model precision and regularization, ultimately leading to diminished inference accuracy and limited acceleration on devices. To address this challenge, we propose introducing a novel sparsity dimension, dubbed pattern-based sparsity, encompassing both pattern and connectivity sparsity. By incorporating carefully crafted patterns, our innovative pruning approach consistently attains unparalleled accuracy enhancements and superior feature extraction capabilities across varied DNN architectures and datasets, while our pattern-aware pruning framework additionally enables pattern library generation, pattern selection, connectivity pruning, and weight training in a single, simultaneous process. Notably, our method seamlessly integrates with compiler optimizations for highly efficient DNN execution on resource-constrained mobile devices.
